383 
FXUS64 KMRX 081917
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
317 PM EDT SAT MAY 8 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY)...POST FRONTAL LOW CLOUDS 
CONTINUE TO DROP SLOWLY SOUTH FROM THE OHIO VALLEY AND CENTRAL 
APPALACHIANS THIS AFTERNOON...WHILE SUNNY SKIES DOMINATE OUR AREA.

AFTERNOON HUMIDITIES STAYING MOSTLY ABOVE 30 PERCENT...AND WHERE A 
FEW SPOTS HAVE DIPPED BELOW 30 PERCENT...WE FIND WIND SPEEDS WELL 
BELOW RED FLAG WARNING LEVELS. IN FACT...OVERALL WINDS HAVE NOT BEEN 
AS BRISK AS EXPECTED. 

TURNING ATTENTION TO NEXT ITEM OF CONCERN...PATCHY FROST POSSIBLE 
OVER NRN HALF OF THE FORECAST AREA OVERNIGHT. I EXPECT SOME OF THE 
LOW CLOUDS TO ADVECT INTO SW VA AND NE TN...AND ALSO WIND SPEEDS 
LOOK TO STAY UP AS WELL. THUS...I SEE NO REASON FOR A FROST ADVISORY
...CHOOSING TO MENTION PATCHY FROST POSSIBLE IN ANY AREA WHERE MINS 
MAY FALL JUST BELOW 40 DEGREES. 

RIDGING ALOFT AND AT THE SURFACE SHOULD KEEP US DRY INTO MONDAY...
AND I DID REMOVE THE LOW POPS FOR LATE SUNDAY NIGHT FOR OUR 
SEQUATCHIE VALLEY COUNTIES. SOUTHERLY LOW LEVEL FLOW RETURNS ON 
MONDAY...WITH MODELS GENERATING A WIDE SWATH OF CONVECTIVE 
PRECIPITATION (PCPN) IN ASSOCIATION WITH A DEVELOPING WARM FRONT.
THIS WARRANTS LOW POPS FOR SRN AND WRN COUNTIES OF EAST TN BY MONDAY 
AFTERNOON. 

OTHERWISE...MOS GUIDANCE TEMPS WERE QUITE CLOSE FOR ALL 4 PERIODS 
AND GENERALLY FOLLOWED.


.LONG TERM...(MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY)...GFS/ECMWF FAIRLY CLOSE 
THROUGHOUT THE LONG TERM DEPICTING INITIAL SHORTWAVE'S PATH EAST 
NORTHEAST ACROSS THE NORTHERN PLAINS INTO THE GREAT LAKES WHILE 
WEAKENING. IT MAY AID IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF SOME WARM AIR ADVECTION 
SHOWERS MONDAY NIGHT INTO EARLY TUESDAY IN ASSOCIATION WITH SURFACE 
LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM. SURFACE LOW SHIFTS EAST ACROSS THE EASTERN 
LAKES WHILE DRAGGING SUFACE BOUNDARY SOUTH ACROSS THE OHIO VALLEY 
TOWARD THE FORECAST AREA THROUGH WEDNESDAY. USED SOME MEDIUM CHANCE 
POPS FOR POSSIBLE WARM FRONTAL SHOWERS/THUNDERSTORMS MONDAY NIGHT 
THEN DROP POPS A BIT FOR TUESDAY INTO TUESDAY NIGHT AS THE SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIAN REGION COMES UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF SYSTEM WARM SECTOR. 
THEN RAISED POPS ON WEDNESDAY INTO LOW CHANCE RANGE AS THE COOL 
FRONT DROPS SOUTH TOWARD THE REGION. DIMINISHED THE PROBABILITY OF 
PRECIPITATION AGAIN FOR THURSDAY AWAITING APPROACH OF NEXT SHORT 
WAVE TROF WHICH PRESSES EAST NORTHEAST INTO THE GREAT LAKES ON 
FRIDAY. SURFACE WAVE WILL BUILD EAST ON A SIMILAR TRACK TAKEN BY THE 
EARLIER WEEK SYSTEM. STAYED WITH SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS IN ANTICIPATION OF THIS LATE WEEK SYSTEM WHICH MAY NOT 
IMPACT THE REGION UNTIL SATURDAY AS SURFACE BOUNDARY SLIPS INTO THE 
SOUTHEASTERN U.S.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION

255 AM EDT SAT MAY 8 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS A 
COLD FRONT GENERALLY ALONG THE CUMBERLAND PLATEAU...WITH A WARM AND 
HUMID AIR MASS STILL LINGERING OVER THE FORECAST AREA. AREA RADARS 
REVEAL A BROKEN THIN LINE OF CONVECTION AHEAD OF THIS FRONT...BUT 
MOST OF THIS CONVECTION SHOULD EXIT THE FORECAST AREA BY AROUND 
SUNRISE. A LARGE DOME OF HIGH PRESSURE OVER THE HIGH PLAINS WILL 
THEN BUILD INTO THE TN RIVER VALLEY TODAY AND TONIGHT...WITH ITS 
TIGHT PRESSURE GRADIENT PRODUCING BREEZY WESTERLY WINDS TODAY. IT 
APPEARS THAT THESE WINDS SHOULD REMAIN BELOW THE WIND ADVISORY 
THRESHOLD OF 25 MPH SUSTAINED WINDS. THE MAIN STORY FOR TODAY 
INVOLVES THE POSSIBILITY OF SOME FIRE WEATHER CONCERNS DUE TO THE 
COMBINATION OF BREEZY WINDS AND LOW AFTERNOON RH'S. WILL PLAN TO 
COORDINATE WITH LOCAL FORESTERS LATER TODAY TO DETERMINE IF A 
SPECIAL WEATHER STATEMENT SHOULD BE ISSUED TO ADDRESS THESE 
CONCERNS. AS FOR TEMPS...GFS AND NAM GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE IN GENERAL 
AGREEMENT FOR TODAY AND TONIGHT...AND LOOK REASONABLE. THIS COLD 
FRONT WILL BRING QUITE A COOL DOWN FOR TODAY...WITH TEMPS AROUND TEN 
TO FIFTEEN DEGREES BELOW NORMAL BY TONIGHT.


.LONG TERM...(SUNDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...MODELS IN GENERAL HAVE SLOWED 
DOWN PROGRESSION OF WARM FRONT WITH BULK OF ASSOCIATED PRECIP NOW 
EXPECTED IN THE LATE MONDAY TO EARLY TUESDAY TIME FRAME. THUS 
LOWERED POPS IN MOST LOCATIONS ON MONDAY WHILE INCREASING POPS INTO 
THE CHANCE CATEGORY MONDAY NIGHT. THIS FRONT IS PROJECTED TO BECOME 
QUASI-STATIONARY JUST NORTH OF OUR CWA THROUGH MID WEEK RESULTING IN 
POTENTIALLY UNSETTLED WEATHER ESPECIALLY FOR OUR NORTHERN TIER 
ZONES. DID NOT MAKE ANY DRASTIC CHANGES TO PRECEDING GRIDS/FORECAST 
WITH RESPECT TO POPS FOR THIS TIME PERIOD. SOUTHEASTERN UPPER RIDGE 
AMPLIFIES IN RESPONSE TO A TROUGH THAT DEVELOPS OVER THE CENTRAL 
PLAINS BY LATE WORK WEEK. THIS HELPS TO PUSH BOUNDARY WELL NORTH OF 
THE AREA WITH ONLY SCATTERED DIURNAL CONVECTION EXPECTED MAINLY IN 
THE HIGHER TERRAIN. CENTRAL PLAINS TROUGH APPROACHES THE SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIAN REGION BY EARLY NEXT WEEKEND...BUT ITS EFFECTS ARE NOT 
EXPECTED BEFORE THE END OF THE LONG TERM PERIOD. FOR TEMPS... 
GENERALLY DID NOT DEVIATE SIGNIFICANTLY FROM MAV/MEX GUIDANCE.

908 
FXUS64 KMRX 071857
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
257 PM EDT FRI MAY 7 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...WARM FRONT IS WELL NOTED ON 
LATEST SURFACE MAPS...LYING FROM ALONG A TYS TO CSV LINE NORTHWARD 
TO NEAR LEXINGTON KY. CONVECTIVE TEMPERATURE IS BEING REACHED ACROSS 
THE FORECAST AREA WITH SOME FLAT CUMULUS CLOUDS DEVELOPING. AREAS 
NEAR THE WARM FRONT HAVE POSITIVE CAPE UP TO 1500 J/KG. HOWEVER...
AREA RADARS LOOK AWFULLY ECHO FREE UPSTREAM...SUCH THAT HAVING OUR 
EVENING HOURS RAINFREE SHOULD WORK. THE WARM AIR ALOFT SHOULD 
CONTINUE TO SUPPRESS CONVECTIVE DEVELOPMENT UNTIL THE FRONT 
APPROACHES.

WILL LIMIT PRECIPITATION TO AFTER MIDNIGHT AND ENDING IN THE WESTERN 
AREAS BEFORE DAYBREAK SATURDAY. THE UPPER LOW AND SUPPORT ALOFT IS 
SO FAR TO OUR NORTH...AND THE CONVECTION ARRIVES SO LATE...THAT 
SCATTERED SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS ARE PROBABLY ALL WE WILL 
SEE WITH THIS SYSTEM. PREVIOUS POP AND WX GRIDS WERE CLOSELY 
FOLLOWED WITH JUST A FEW TWEAKS. 

SHOULD BE ON THE BREEZY SIDE SATURDAY AFTER FRONTAL PASSAGE...BUT FOR
NOW KEPT WIND SPEEDS BELOW ADVISORY CRITERIA...WITH SOME GUSTS AS 
HIGH AS 35 MPH. MIN RH VALUES SATURDAY AFTERNOON WOULD APPEAR TO RUN 
ABOUT 5 PERCENT ABOVE CRITICAL VALUES FOR SW VA AND SW NC FIRE 
DISTRICTS...WITH SPEEDS ALSO NEAR CRITERIA FOR A RED FLAG WARNING.
HOWEVER...WET WEATHER FROM PAST WEEKEND AND ANY RAIN OVERNIGHT 
SHOULD HELP...SO WILL PASS THIS CONCERN ON TO THE FOLLOWING SHIFTS.  

OTHERWISE...NEXT CONCERN IS FOR SATURDAY NIGHT WITH COLDER TEMPS 
BROUGHT IN WITH THE NORTHERLY FLOW. MIN TEMPS FALL ENOUGH FOR SOME 
PATCHY FROST ACROSS SW VA AND SOME OTHER HIGH TERRAIN...BUT GRADIENT 
AND WINDS ALOFT SHOULD KEEP A NORTH WIND OF 5 TO 15 MPH. THIS SHOULD
PREVENT FROST FROM FORMING. 

MOS GUIDANCE WAS CLOSE AND REASONABLE FOR ALL BUT SATURDAY HIGHS. 
FOR SATURDAY MAX TEMPS I WENT FOR A BLEND CLOSER TO THE MILDER GFS 
NUMBERS. 


.LONG TERM...(SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY)...MODELS RELATIVELY CLOSE 
THROUGH MID WEEK WITH SOLUTIONS DIVERGING BY THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. 
STAYED CLOSER TO THE ECMWF FOR THIS PACKAGE. THE ATMOSPHERE WILL BE 
GRADUALLY MOISTENING ON RETURN SOUTHERLY FLOW SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH 
THE MIDDLE OF NEXT WEEK AS ANOTHER UPPER LEVEL TROF SWINGS NORTHEAST 
FROM THE DESERT SOUTHWEST TOWARD THE MIDWEST. SURFACE LOW PRESSURE 
MOVES NORTHEAST FROM THE CENTRAL ROCKIES MONDAY INTO THE GREAT LAKES 
STATES BY 12Z WEDNESDAY. LEFT SLIGHT AND CHANCE VARIETY POPS FOR 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS THROUGH THURSDAY AS THE FORECAST AREA WILL 
BE IN THE WAA PATTERN AHEAD OF THE STORM SYSTEM EARLY IN THE WEEK 
AND THEN SYSTEM COOL FRONT WILL DROP INTO THE NORTHERN PART OF THE 
VIEWING AREA LATER WEDNESDAY INTO THURSDAY. KEPT POPS OUT OF THE 
FORECAST FOR THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT AS THE UPPER LEVEL 
HEIGHT PATTERN AMPLIFIES AGAIN WITH THE APPROACH OF ANOTHER SHORT 
WAVE TROF WHICH IS PROGGED TO BUILD NORTHEAST INTO THE GREAT LAKES 
KEEPING ANY CHANCE OF RAIN RATHER LOW ACROSS THE SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIAN REGION.

&&

149 
FXUS64 KMRX 070650
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
250 AM EDT FRI MAY 7 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS A 
QUASI-STATIONARY FRONTAL BOUNDARY LOCATED BETWEEN KNOXVILLE AND THE 
TRI-CITIES...WITH A LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM CENTERED OVER THE CENTRAL 
PLAINS. THIS LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM IS PROGGED TO MOVE NORTHEAST INTO 
THE GREAT LAKES REGION TODAY...WITH ITS TRAILING COLD FRONT MOVING 
ACROSS THE TN RIVER VALLEY TONIGHT. A STRONG SOUTHERLY WIND FLOW 
AHEAD OF THIS SYSTEM WILL PUSH THE LOCAL STALLED FRONTAL BOUNDARY 
NORTHWARD INTO THE MID ATLANTIC STATES BY THIS AFTERNOON. THESE 
SOUTHERLY WINDS WILL BECOME FAIRLY BREEZY AREAWIDE BY THIS 
AFTERNOON...BUT SHOULD REMAIN BELOW THE ADVISORY THRESHOLD OF 25 MPH 
SUSTAINED WINDS. MODEL SOUNDINGS REVEAL A FAIRLY DRY AIR MASS OVER 
THE REGION TODAY...BUT WILL PLAN TO MENTION ISOLATED AFTERNOON 
CONVECTION ACROSS THE MOUNTAINS WHERE UPSLOPE FLOW MAY HELP TO 
TRIGGER A FEW TSTORMS (SIMILAR TO YESTERDAY). MODELS ARE IN GOOD 
AGREEMENT THAT THE COLD FRONT WILL MOVE THROUGH THE FORECAST AREA 
AFTER MIDNIGHT TONIGHT...WITH ENOUGH MOISTURE FOR SOME SCATTERED 
CONVECTION. IF THIS CONVECTION STAYS AHEAD OF THE COLD FRONT...MODEL 
SOUNDINGS INDICATE THAT AN INVERTED-V VERTICAL TEMP PROFILE MAY 
CREATE SOME STRONG GUSTY WINDS WITH A FEW STORMS. AS FOR TEMPS... 
GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE IN GOOD AGREEMENT FOR TODAY...BUT REVEAL SOME 
DISCREPANCIES FOR TONIGHT. WILL PLAN TO FORECAST MAXES TO BE A FEW 
DEGREES WARMER TODAY (COMPARED TO YESTERDAY)...AND WILL TREND CLOSER 
TO THE COOLER NAM NUMBERS FOR TONIGHT. 


.LONG TERM...(SATURDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...FRONT PULLS AWAY FROM 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION EARLY SATURDAY TAKING PRECIP WITH IT... 
BUT USHERING IN SIGNIFICANTLY COOLER AIR. BOUNDARY RETURNS AS WARM 
FRONT BY MONDAY WITH AN ASSOCIATED INCREASE IN POPS THROUGH THE DAY. 
PRECIP SHIFTS NORTH OF THE FORECAST AREA BY TUESDAY AS WEAK UPPER 
RIDGING PUSHES WARM FRONT TO THE NORTH. HOWEVER...BOUNDARY LURKS 
CLOSE ENOUGH TO KEEP THINGS POTENTIALLY UNSETTLED THROUGH MID WEEK 
BEFORE UPPER RIDGE AMPLIFIES PUSHING FRONT EVEN FARTHER NORTH BY 
LATE WEEK. DID KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR DAYTIME PERIODS LATE IN 
THE LONG TERM TO ACCOUNT FOR POTENTIAL DIURNAL CONVECTION IN WARM 
SECTOR. TEMPS ARE EXPECTED TO RECOVER FROM WELL BELOW CLIMO EARLY IN 
THE LONG TERM TO A RETURN TO ABOVE CLIMO TEMPS BY MID WEEK. 
GENERALLY DID NOT DEVIATE SIGNIFICANTLY FROM MAV/MEX GUIDANCE.

FXUS64 KMRX 061910
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
310 PM EDT THU MAY 6 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY THROUGH SATURDAY)...WEAK COLD FRONT APPEARS TO 
HAVE PASSED SE THROUGH THE ENTIRE FORECAST AREA THIS AFTERNOON...
WITH LITTLE IF ANY EFFECTS OTHER THAN A SLIGHT DROP IN DEW POINT 
TEMPS. SOME FLAT CUMULUS CLOUDS OVER MAINLY HIGHER TERRAIN AREAS...
BUT THIS SHOULD DISSIPATE THIS EVENING AND GIVE WAY TO MOSTLY CLEAR 
SKIES OVERNIGHT. TYS WAS ONE OF THE MILDER MIN TEMP SPOTS LAST
NIGHT DUE TO A LIGHT SW WIND...WHICH SHOULD BE ABSENT TONIGHT.
OPTED TO GO CLOSE TO THE REASONABLE MOS MINS.

DON'T FORESEE MUCH CHANGE FOR FRIDAY FROM TODAY...AS DRY AND WARM 
WEATHER LINGERS. SHOULD SEE A SLIGHT INCREASE IN DAYTIME CUMULUS 
CLOUDS AND SOME SPOTS GETTING CLOSE TO RECORD HIGHS (WHICH ARE 
MOSTLY UPPER 80S TO LOWER 90S).

MODEL CONSENSUS WAS TO DELAY CONVECTION UNTIL AFTER MIDNIGHT FRIDAY 
NIGHT...WITH BEST CHANCES RUNNING FROM 06Z TO JUST AFTER 12Z 
SATURDAY. CHANCE POPS WITH AREAL SCATTERED QUALIFIER LOOKED GOOD
WITH DEFINITELY A MENTION OF THUNDERSTORMS IN ORDER. HOWEVER...
I WOULD NOT BE SURPRISED TO SEE MUCH LESS THAN A SOLID LINE OF WEAK 
CONVECTION WITH THIS FRONT. RAIN CHANCES DROP OUT AFTER SATURDAY 
MORNING...FOLLOWED BY CLEARING SKIES...COOLER TEMPS AND BREEZY 
CONDITIONS. GENERALLY FOLLOWED MOS NUMBERS FOR LOWS FRIDAY NIGHT AND 
HIGHS SATURDAY.


.LONG TERM...(SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY)...WAS ABLE TO KEEP THE 
FIRST DAY AND A HALF...SATURDAY NIGHT/SUNDAY...FREE OF PROBABILITY 
OF PRECIPITATION AS DRY ADVECTION AND SURFACE RIDGINS KEEP THE 
THREAT OF RAIN AWAY. HOWEVER...WAS FORCED TO ADD A POP IN THROUGH 
ABOUT MID WEEK AS ATMOSPHERE MOISTENS AND DESTABILIZES A BIT. BEST 
LIFTING APPEARS TO BE CENTERED AROUND MONDAY AND TUESDAY AS WARM 
FRONT WILL BE MAKING PROGRESS NORTH ACROSS THE MID SOUTH AS UPPER 
TROF AMPLIFIES OVER THE PLAINS STATES. THIS WILL DRIVE A SURFACE LOW 
PRESSURE SYSTEM NORTHEAST FROM THE PLAINS INTO THE GREAT LAKES. BY 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT INTO THURSDAY THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION SHOULD 
BE IN THE WARM SECTOR WITH ONLY A SLIGHT CHANCE OF CONVECTION IN THE 
MAJOR TERRAIN AREAS. STAYED FAIRLY CLOSE TO PREVIOUS PACKAGE TEMP 
FORECAST WITH MINOR TWEAKS TOWARD NEW MOS GUIDANCE.

318 PM EDT WED MAY 5 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY)...THESE PERIODS LOOK TO
REMAIN DRY AND WARM WITH A CHANCE EACH DAY (ALTHOUGH BETTER REGION

92...TRI 87 AND OQT 88).

ZONAL FLOW ALOFT AMPLIFIES ON THURSDAY THEN FLATTENS BY FRIDAY NIGHT 
AS A LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM TRACKS EAST FROM THE UPPER MS VALLEY 
THROUGH THE GREAT LAKES REGION. THE ASSOCIATED TRAILING COLD FRONT
MAY BRING SCATTERED SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS FRIDAY
NIGHT. PRIOR TO THIS SYSTEM A WEAK COLD FRONT WILL MOVE SE ACROSS
THE OHIO VALLEY EARLY THURSDAY AND MAY DRIFT THROUGH THE SRN
APPALACHIANS BY THURSDAY AFTERNOON OR EVENING. DON'T SEE MUCH
MOISTURE WITH THIS FRONT...SO OPTED TO KEEP THESE FIRST 4 PERIODS
DRY FOR NOW.

MOS MAX TEMPS GENERALLY CLOSE AND FOLLOWED. MIN TEMP GUIDANCE FOR 
TONIGHT LOOKS A LITTLE MILD GIVEN THE CLEAR SKIES...DRY AIRMASS AND 
VERY LIGHT WINDS...SO WENT A DEGREE OR TWO BELOW GFS MOS FOR TONIGHT.
A BLEND OF MOS MINS LOOKED GOOD FOR THURSDAY NIGHT.


.LONG TERM...(FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...AN AREA OF LOW
PRESSURE TRACKS TO THE NORTH OF THE CWA ON FRIDAY NIGHT AND
SATURDAY WITH A COLD FRONT ASSOCIATED WITH IT TRACKS SOUTH INTO THE
CWA ON FRIDAY NIGHT INTO SATURDAY MORNING. WILL KEEP THE CHANCE
POPS FOR BOTH PERIODS WITH THE HIGHER CHANCES IN THE NORTH NEARER
THE AREA OF LOW PRESSURE. DRY WEATHER RETURNS BRIEFLY BEFORE A WARM
FRONT PUSHED INTO THE AREA ON MONDAY AND LINGERS INTO TUESDAY. WITH
STILL SOME UNCERTAINTY ON TIMING...WILL KEEP ONLY SLIGHT CHANCE
POPS FOR NOW. A FEW TIMING DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THE ECMWF AND THE
GFS ON WEDNESDAY. WILL GO WITH THE DRIER GFS AND KEEP WEDNESDAY DRY
FOR NOW. STAYED NEAR MEX/HPC GUIDANCE FOR TEMPERATURES.

719 
FXUS64 KMRX 041835
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
235 PM EDT TUE MAY 4 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY)...SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE WILL 
CONTINUE TO PROVIDE TRANQUIL WEATHER CONDITIONS THROUGH THE SHORT 
TERM. FLOW ALOFT WILL REMAIN NEARLY ZONAL WHICH WILL ALLOW GOOD 
WARMING OF THE BOUNDARY LAYER UNDER STRONG MAY SOLAR INSOLATION... 
RESULTING IN ANTICIPATED WELL-ABOVE-CLIMO MAX TEMPS ON WEDNESDAY. 
DID NOT DEVIATE SIGNIFICANTLY FROM MAV GUIDANCE VALUES AS THEY SEEM 
REASONABLE GIVEN EXPECTED SCENARIO.


.LONG TERM...(WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY)...
A RIDGE WILL BE BUILDING OVER THE SOUTHEAST CONUS THROUGH THURSDAY 
NIGHT. THIS SHOULD HELP SUPPRESS CONVECTION THURSDAY AFTERNOON 
DESPITE PLENTY OF SURFACE HEATING. THERE COULD BE AN ISOLATED SHOWER 
IN THE MOUNTAINS...BUT CHANCES APPEAR TOO SMALL TO MENTION IN THE 
FORECAST AT THIS TIME. 

ONCE THE RIDGE AXIS SHIFTS EAST ON FRIDAY...A SW FLOW WILL ADVECT 
SOME LOW LEVEL MOISTURE INTO THE AREA AHEAD OF AN APPROACHING COLD 
FRONT. INSTABILITY AHEAD OF THE FRONT SHOULD RESULT IN ISOLATED 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FRIDAY AFTERNOON...THEN WILL RAISE POPS TO 
A CHANCE FRIDAY NIGHT WITH THE FROPA. LIFT IS NOT VERY STRONG WITH 
THE FRONT AS THE UPPER LEVEL FLOW REMAINS NEARLY ZONAL AND THE UPPER 
JET STAYS WELL TO THE NORTH. HOWEVER THERE IS A GOOD PUSH OF A COLD 
AIR MASS IN THE LOW LEVELS BEHIND THE FRONT...WHICH WILL BRING 
COOLER TEMPS FOR THE WEEKEND. LOW TEMPS COULD DROP INTO THE 30S 
SATURDAY NIGHT AND SUNDAY NIGHT IN SOME SPOTS...WITH HIGHS IN THE 
MID 60S TO LOWER 70S.

LOW PRESSURE THAT DEVELOPS IN THE LEE OF THE ROCKIES WILL GIVE A 
SOUTHERLY FLOW OF WARMER AND MORE MOIST AIR BY MONDAY. THE GFS AND 
ECMWF DEPICT A WARM FRONT PUSHING NORTHWARD ON MONDAY NIGHT...THOUGH 
ENSEMBLES DIFFER ON TIMING. WILL CONTINUE A SLIGHT CHANCE POP FOR 
MONDAY AND TUESDAY.

FXUS64 KMRX 040645
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
245 AM EDT TUE MAY 4 2010

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE WILL MOVE 
EAST ACROSS THE AREA THROUGH PERIOD. UPPER TROF AXIS WILL MOVE EAST 
ACROSS THE AREA EARLY TODAY. SOME PATCHY FOG THIS MORNING WILL BURN 
OFF QUICKLY. MID CLOUD DECK WILL MOVE NE ACROSS N PART OF AREA THIS 
MORNING. TEMPS WILL BE ABOVE NORMAL. 

.LONG TERM...(WEDNESDAY THROUGH MONDAY)...FAST ZONAL FLOW AND SURFACE
RIDGING WILL START THE EXTEND ON WEDNESDAY WITH AN UPPER TROUGH 
MOVING ACROSS THE GREAT LAKES. A WARM AND DRY AIRMASS IS IN PLACE 
FOR WEDNESDAY.

FOR WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY...A WEAK FRONT TRIES TO MOVE INTO 
THE LOWER OHIO VALLEY AND CENTRAL APPALACHIANS BUT REMAINS NORTH OF 
THE FORECAST AREA. AIRMASS REMAINS QUITE DRY WITH PWS BELOW 1 INCH. 
HOWEVER...ENOUGH LOW-LEVEL MOISTURE RETURN WITH DEWPOINTS IN THE 50S 
TO POSSIBLY PRODUCE ISOLATED CONVECTION OVER THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS 
THURSDAY AFTERNOON-EVENING.

FOR THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY...ANOTHER SHORT-WAVE MOVES ACROSS THE 
NORTHERN SECTIONS OF THE NATION (NORTHERN PLAINS TOWARD THE GREAT 
LAKES) WITH CONTINUED FAST ZONAL FLOW OVER THE SOUTHERN UNITED 
STATES. COLD FRONT ASSOCIATED WITH GREAT LAKES UPPER TROUGH WILL 
MOVE INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY FRIDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING.  DUE TO 
RIDGING INTO THE GULF...MOISTURE AND INSTABILITY VERY LIMITED AHEAD 
OF FRONT...SO ANY CONVECTION WILL LIKELY BE AFTER FROPA. WILL CARRY 
LOW CHANCE POPS FOR FRIDAY NIGHT-EARLY SATURDAY MORNING.

FOR SATURDAY AND SUNDAY...UPPER TROUGH MOVES EAST ACROSS THE 
NORTHEAST UNITED STATES WITH SURFACE RIDGING BUILD INTO THE SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIANS PRODUCING DRY AND COOLER WEATHER.

FOR SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY...SURFACE RIDGING MOVES EAST OF THE 
FORECAST AREA WITH RETURN OF SOUTHERLY WINDS PRODUCING SOME 
ISENTROPIC ADVECTION. WILL CONTINUE WITH A CHANCE OF SHOWERS FOR LATE
SUNDAY NIGHT AND MONDAY.

VALLEY REGION FOR THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. NEXT WEAK FRONTAL BOUNDARY

SHOULD APPROACH THE AREA BY MONDAY AFTERNOON. HAVE INTRODUCED A

824 
FXUS64 KMRX 030024
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
825 PM EDT SUN MAY 2 2010

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS A NORTH-TO-SOUTH ORIENTED COLD FRONT 
EXTENDING FROM NEAR INDIANAPOLIS SOUTHWARD TO GENERALLY ALONG THE TN 
RIVER BETWEEN NASHVILLE AND JACKSON TN. AN UNSEASONABLY WARM AND 
HUMID AIR MASS REMAINS OVER THE FORECAST AREA...WITH WATER VAPOR 
SATELLITE IMAGERY REVEALING THAT THE HIGH MOISTURE CONTENT EXTENDS 
IN A LONG PLUME FROM THE EASTERN PACIFIC OCEAN AND GULF OF MEXICO. 
MODELS INDICATE THAT THE UPPER-LEVEL WINDS (WHICH HAVE BEEN PARALLEL 
TO THE FRONTAL BOUNDARY...PREVENTING MUCH OF AN EASTWARD PUSH) WILL 
BECOME MORE SOUTHWESTERLY TONIGHT...WHICH SHOULD HELP TO PUSH THIS 
FRONTAL BOUNDARY A LITTLE FASTER TO THE EAST OVERNIGHT INTO MONDAY. 
HOWEVER...MODELS INDICATE THAT AN UPPER-LEVEL SHORT WAVE WILL HELP 
TO INTENSIFY CONVECTIVE DEVELOPMENT AHEAD OF THIS FRONT AS IT MOVES 
INTO THE FORECAST AREA AFTER MIDNIGHT. THUS...IT STILL APPEARS THAT 
RAINFALL COULD BECOME HEAVY AT TIMES...WITH A FLOODING THREAT 
CONTINUING OVERNIGHT INTO MONDAY MORNING.

OVERALL...CURRENT FORECAST AND FLASH FLOOD WATCH APPEAR TO BE ON 
TRACK...BUT WILL PLAN TO UPDATE THE ZONES THIS EVENING TO REMOVE THE 
MENTION OF THE SEVERE TSTORM WATCH.
&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...

240 PM EDT SUN MAY 2 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND MONDAY)...BAND OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS TO OUR WEST WILL FINALLY MOVE INTO AND ACROSS OUR AREA 
DURING THE SHORT TERM...AS SLOW MOVING FRONT FINALLY PUSHES 
THROUGH.  STRONG LOW LEVEL JET BRINGING ABUNDANT MOISTURE INTO THE 
AREA...SO STILL LOOKS LIKE THERE IS THE POSSIBILITY OF SOME 
FLOODING.  WILL KEEP FLASH FLOOD WATCH...ALTHOUGH WILL SHORTEN A BIT 
AS APPEARS PRECIP MAY MOVE OUT OF THE AREA A BIT FASTER.  WITH 
SIGNIFICANT LOW LEVEL SHEAR AVAILABLE...SOME SEVERE STORMS WILL BE 
POSSIBLE AS WELL AND AN ISOLATED TORNADO CANNOT BE RULED OUT.  WILL 
NOT STRAY FAR FROM MAV TEMPS.  


.LONG TERM...(MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...A RETURN TO GENERALLY 
MORE TRANQUIL CONDITIONS EXPECTED THROUGH THE LONG TERM PER MODEL 
AND ENSEMBLE CONSENSUS. CONTINUED DRY FORECAST FOR SEVERAL MID-WEEK 
PERIODS. CONSIDERABLE MODEL DISCREPANCIES LOWER CONFIDENCE IN SYSTEM 
THAT APPROACHES BY LATE WORK WEEK...ESPECIALLY WITH RESPECT TO 
TIMING. GIVEN THE TIMING UNCERTAINTIES...GENERALLY DID NOT MAKE 
SIGNIFICANT CHANGES TO PRECEDING GRIDS/FORECAST. A RETURN TO DRY 
WEATHER IS PROJECTED FOR LATE IN THE LONG TERM PERIOD. FOR TEMPS... 
GENERALLY TENDED TO FAVOR SLIGHTLY COOLER HPC GUIDANCE VALUES.

SEVERE THREAT LATER TODAY INTO TONIGHT...AND FLOODING STILL LOOKS
POSSIBLE...SO WILL LEAVE FFA AS IS. WILL SLOW ONSET OF PRECIP IN
THE DATABASE...AND LOWER POPS FOR ALL BUT FAR WESTERN AREAS. WILL
ALSO LOWER SKY COVER A BIT AND RAISE MAX TEMPS. UPDATE OUT SOON.

FXUS64 KMRX 020808
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
400 AM EDT SUN MAY 2 2010

.SHORT TERM (TODAY THROUGH MONDAY)...STRONG SW-NE JET WILL AGAIN 
STRENGTHEN TODAY ACROSS THE WESTERN TN VLY. THE JET CORE WILL 
EVENTUALLY MOVE N OF THE AREA BY THE END OF THE PERIOD WITH THE JET 
AXIS REMAINING WEST OF THE MRX CWA. TEMPERATURES THROUGH THE LAYER 
ARE VERY WARM AND TREMENDOUS MOISTURE TRANSPORT FROM THE GLFMEX INTO 
THE REGION WILL CONTINUE. PW VALUES WILL CLIMB TO NEAR 2.00. 
PRECIPITATION EFFICIENCY LOOKS VERY GOOD. HOURLY RAINFALL RATES 
ALONE WILL BE IMPRESSIVE BUT TRAINING CELLS WILL ALSO INCREASE THE 
FLASH FLOOD THREAT ACROSS THE REGION. AIRMASS DESTABILIZES MORE 
TODAY THAN DEPICTED IN PREVIOUS MODEL RUNS. CAPE VALUES GET 
MODERATELY HIGH BY THIS AFTERNOON. LOW LEVEL HELICITY FAVORABLE FOR 
TORNADO DEVELOPMENT. SUPERCELL COMPOSITE AND TORNADO PARAMETERS ARE 
IMPRESSIVE TO THE W TODAY AND PORTRAY A MINOR THREAT LATER THIS 
AFTERNOON FOR THE MRX CWA.   

.LONG TERM (MONDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY)...EARLY IN THE 
PERIOD...THE WEEKEND WEATHER MAKER WILL BE EXITING THE REGION WITH A 
SECONDARY WEAK BOUNDARY SLIDING THROUGH TO OUR NORTH.  HAVE LEFT 20 
TO 30 POPS MONDAY NIGHT AND TUESDAY.  WILL BE BETWEEN WEATHER 
SYSTEMS AND IN A QUIET WEATHER PATTERN WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY.  THE 
NEXT SYSTEM IS PROGGED INTO THE REGION AROUND FOR FRIDAY/FRIDAY 
NIGHT TIME FRAME.  HAVE CONTINUED LOW POPS FOR FRIDAY AND INCREASE 
POPS TO 30 FRIDAY NIGHT...WITH ONLY A FEW LINGERING SHOWERS POSSIBLE 
FAR EASTERN MOUNTAINS ON SATURDAY.

AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
246 PM EDT SAT MAY 1 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND SUNDAY)...FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL PUSH 
CLOSER...BUT STILL SHOULD BE TO OUR WEST THROUGH SUNDAY.  AXIS OF 
THE HEAVIER RAIN SHOULD STAY TO OUR WEST AS WELL DURING THE PERIOD.  
WILL HAVE TO CARRY CHANCE POPS TONIGHT...THEN WILL INCREASE TO CAT 
POPS FAR WEST...LIKELY CENTRAL AND CHANCE FAR EAST/NORTHEAST ZONES 
SUNDAY AFTERNOON. SEVERE THREAT MAY BIT HIGHER SUNDAY AS WELL IF 
MODEST FORECAST INSTABILITY INCREASE IS REALIZED.  GFS MOS TEMPS 
GENERALLY LOOK REASONABLE...SO WILL NOT STRAY FAR.    


.LONG TERM...(SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY)...HEIGHT OF UPCOMING 
EVENT STILL APPEARS TO BE FOCUSED IN THE SUNDAY NIGHT TO MONDAY 
MORNING TIME FRAME BASED ON LATEST MODEL AND SREF RUNS. GREATEST
AMOUNTS OF RAINFALL EXPECTED ON PLATEAU WITH AMOUNTS DECREASING
SOMEWHAT EASTWARD. STILL APPEARS TO BE A POTENTIALLY SIGNIFICANT
RAIN EVENT FOR THE ENTIRE CWA HOWEVER...AND WILL ISSUE SPS TO COVER
POTENTIAL. SYSTEM MOVES OUT BY LATE MONDAY WITH DRY PERIOD
EXPECTED THROUGH MUCH OF THE WORK WEEK. STILL SOME UNCERTAINTY
ABOUT MID WEEK AS ECMWF DEPICTS SHORT WAVE TRANSLATING THROUGH THE
SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION...BUT LEFT THOSE PERIODS DRY FOR NOW.
NEXT POTENTIALLY SIGNIFICANT SYSTEM APPROACHES BY LATE IN THE LONG
TERM BUT SIGNIFICANT TIMING ISSUES PRECLUDE ANY CONFIDENCE OF WHEN
THIS FEATURE WILL ACTUALLY AFFECT OUR REGION. THUS SPREAD SLIGHT
CHANCE POPS OVER SEVERAL PERIODS TO ACCOUNT FOR UNCERTAINTY. FOR
TEMPS...TENDED TO SLIGHTLY UNDERCUT MEX TEMPS FOR MID WEEK AS THEY
APPEAR TOO WARM GIVEN EXPECTED SCENARIO.

AREA. OTHERWISE OROGRAPHIC LIFT BEST LAUNCHING MECHANISM THROUGH 
PERIOD. VERY WARM TEMPS...ESPECIALLY TONIGHT.

DISCREPANCY IN TIMING OF APPROACHING SYSTEM...BUT LATE SUNDAY NIGHT 
INTO EARLY MONDAY MORNING STILL LOOKS LIKE BEST FIT.  HAVE KEPT POPS 
CATEGORICAL LATE SUNDAY NIGHT AND OVER THE EASTERN AREAS SUNDAY 
MORNING.  ALSO OF CONCERN IS STRONG WINDS ACCOMPANYING THE SYSTEM 
AND EXPECTED WINDS TO BECOME STRONG AND GUSTY AS THE FRONT PASSES 
THROUGH.  TRENDING POPS LOWER THROUGH THE DAY WITH 30 TO 40 POPS FOR 
MONDAY NIGHT.  A FEW SHOWERS MAY LINGER INTO TUESDAY AS A WEAKENING 
SECONDARY BOUNDARY MOVES THROUGH TO OUR NORTH.  WILL BE BETWEEN 
THINGS WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY.  BY FRIDAY...MODELS DIVERGING...COULD 
SEE THE NEXT SYSTEM MOVING INTO THE AREA THOUGH CONFIDENCE LOW ON 
TIMING.  FOR NOW WILL CONTINUE WITH A DRY FORECAST.

FXUS64 KMRX 301902
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
302 PM EDT FRI APR 30 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND SATURDAY)...SATELLITE SHOWS CLOUDS
INCREASING FAIRLY RAPIDLY FROM THE SOUTHWEST TOWARDS THE FORECAST
AREA. MODELS SHOW INCREASING ISENTROPIC LIFT WITH GULF MOISTURE
SPREADING INTO THE FORECAST AREA OVERNIGHT WITH CLOUDS BECOMING
OVERCAST AT CHA EARLY THIS EVENING...TYS BY MIDNIGHT...AND TRI
TOWARD DAYBREAK.

FOR SATURDAY...MAIN FOCUS MECHANISM WILL BE OROGRAPHIC LIFT.
ISENTROPIC LIFT WILL ALSO BE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. MODEL
SOUNDINGS SHOW PWS INCREASING TO 1.6 TO 1.8 INCHES BY AFTERNOON
WITH CAPES APPROACHING 1000 J/KG (MORE ACROSS THE PLATEAU COUNTIES).
CAN NOT RULE OUT ISOLATED SEVERE ACROSS THE PLATEAU AND SOUTHEAST
TENNESSEE...BUT THE THREAT IS LOW WITH THE MAIN CONCERN BEING
DAMAGING WINDS. ALSO...LOCALIZED HEAVY RAIN AND RUNOFF PROBLEMS ARE
A CONCERN...MAINLY ACROSS THE PLATEAU AND SOUTHEAST TENNESSEE.

GENERALLY TRENDED TOWARD GFS MOS TEMPERATURES.

.LONG TERM (SATURDAY NIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY)...PEAK EVENT OF 
APPROACHING SYSTEM STILL EXPECTED IN THE LATE SUNDAY THROUGH EARLY 
MONDAY TIME FRAME PER MODEL/SREF CONSENSUS AS FRONT PROGRESSES 
THROUGH THE AREA. CONTINUED CATEGORICAL POPS FOR THE SUNDAY NIGHT 
PERIOD WITH GENERALLY SCATTERED CONVECTION PRECEDING AND SUCCEEDING 
MAIN EVENT. GFS AND SREF PROJECT AROUND TWO INCHES STORM TOTAL 
PRECIP GENERALLY WITH THIS SYSTEM WHICH SEEMS REASONABLE. CONTINUED 
TO SLOWLY TAPER OFF POPS THROUGH TUESDAY AND LEAVING BALANCE OF THE 
LONG TERM DRY FOR NOW. ANOTHER SYSTEM APPROACHES BY LATE NEXT WEEK BUT 
EFFECT APPEAR WILL NOT BE FELT UNTIL AFTER THE LONG TERM. FOR 
TEMPS...GENERALLY DID NOT DEVIATE MUCH FROM MAV/MEX GUIDANCE.

SHIFT EAST DURING THE PERIOD AS SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE CONTINUES TO 
EXTEND IN FROM THE SOUTHEAST. WILL SEE A FEW CLOUDS AROUND AT 
TIMES...BUT SHOULD BE CLEAR TO MOSTLY CLEAR THROUGH THE PERIOD.  
WILL NOT STRAY FAR FROM MAV TEMPS.  


.LONG TERM...(FRIDAY NIGHT THROUGH THURSDAY)...MODELS AND ENSEMBLES 
REMAIN IN REASONABLY GOOD AGREEMENT WITH SLOW-MOVING...POTENTIALLY
SIGNIFICANT SYSTEM THAT APPROACHES THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION
THIS WEEKEND. APPEARS MAIN EVENT WILL OCCUR IN THE LATE SUNDAY TO
EARLY MONDAY TIME FRAME WITH MORE SCATTERED COVERAGE BRACKETING THE
PERIODS AROUND THIS TIME FRAME. MODEL SOLUTIONS BEGIN TO DIVERGE BY
THE MIDDLE OF NEXT WEEK AS GFS DEPICTS UPPER SHORT WAVE TROUGH
TRANSLATING THOUGH THE REGION ON TUESDAY WHILE THE ECMWF DEPICTS
GENERALLY DRY CONDITIONS. DID NOT MAKE ANY SIGNIFICANT CHANGES TO
PRECEDING GRIDS/FORECAST DUE TO THIS UNCERTAINTY. WENT DRY FOR LATE
IN THE LONG TERM. DISCOUNTED THE 00Z GFS DEPICTION OF AN UPPER
TROUGH OVER THE EASTERN CONUS BY LATE IN THE LONG TERM AS IT HAS NO
SUPPORT FROM ANY OF THE GEFS ENSEMBLE MEMBERS OR THE ECMWF. ALSO
WENT WELL ABOVE MEX GUIDANCE TEMPS FOR BOTH WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY
DUE TO THIS ANOMALOUS DEPICTION.

FXUS64 KMRX 290747
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
345 AM EDT THU APR 29 2010

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...FAIR WEATHER PATTERN TO CONTINUE 
TODAY AND TONIGHT AS UPPER RIDGE AXIS SHIFTS SLOWLY EAST TO THE 
APPALACHIANS. SOME CI SPILLING OVER THE TOP OF THE RIDGE BUT THE 
BALANCE OF THE DAY WILL BE SUNNY. THE INSOLATION IN COMBINATION WITH 
A SHIFT TO LOW LEVEL SOUTHERLY FLOW WILL ALLOW HIGH TEMPERATURES TO 
BOUNCE BACK TO NORMAL FOR LATE APRIL. IT WON'T BE QUITE AS COOL 
TONIGHT AS MILDER AIR CONTINUES TO ADVECT INTO THE REGION ON LIGHT 
SOUTHERLY WINDS. MAINTAINED THE FROST ADVISORY STATEMENT FOR THE 
EXPECTED THREAT THIS MORNING.

.LONG TERM (FRIDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...HIGH PRESSURE BECOMES 
ANCHORED OFF THE ATLANTIC COAST ON FRIDAY...PROVIDING A GOOD LOW 
LEVEL SOUTHERLY FLOW OFF THE GULF. INCREASING MOISTURE ADVECTION 
WILL BRING A GOOD CHANCE OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS FOR 
SATURDAY....BEGINNING AN EXTENDED WET PERIOD FOR THE AREA. A 
SLOW-MOVING CLOSED LOW OVER THE NORTHERN PLAINS AND THE POSITIONING 
OF THE JET STREAM ACROSS THE MID MS VALLEY AND GREAT LAKES WILL 
PROVIDE AN UNSETTLED PATTERN THROUGH MONDAY. CATEGORICAL TO LIKELY 
POPS SEEM WARRANTED DURING THIS TIME FRAME AS THE GFS AND ECMWF ARE 
IN GOOD AGREEMENT WITH THE WET PATTERN...AND GFS ENSEMBLES SHOW GOOD 
AGREEMENT. MODELS HAVE SHOWN GOOD RUN-TO-RUN CONSISTENCY AS WELL. 
THE BEST PRECIP CHANCES LOOK TO BE ON SUNDAY WHEN A 850 MB FRONT 
APPROACHES THE AREA...AND THE UPPER JET MOVES INTO A MORE FAVORABLE 
POSITION OVER THE OHIO VALLEY/GREAT LAKES TO PROVIDE ENHANCED 
DIVERGENCE ALOFT. GIVEN THE POTENTIAL EXTENDED WET PERIOD AND THE 
PERSISTENT SOUTH-SOUTHWESTERLY FLOW...THE THREAT FOR FLOODING WILL 
NEED TO BE MONITORED AS THE WEEKEND APPROACHES. THOUGH THE FRONT 
MOVES THROUGH THE AREA MONDAY AND MOISTURE DECREASES...THE PASSAGE 
OF THE UPPER TROUGH SHOULD KEEP RAIN CHANCES GOING INTO TUESDAY. 
ANOTHER CLOSED LOW CROSSES THE GREAT LAKES ON WEDNESDAY...SO WILL 
KEEP CHANCE POPS GOING FOR DAY 7.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
310 PM EDT WED APR 28 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT AND THURSDAY)...SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE OVER 
THE REGION WILL DRIFT EAST AND CONTINUE TO EXTEND INTO OUR AREA 
THROUGH THE PERIOD.  EXPECT A MOSTLY CLEAR SKY AND DRY WEATHER. 
POSSIBLY SOME AREAS OF FROST LATE TONIGHT FOR ESPECIALLY NORTHERN 
AND MOUNTAIN AREAS...INCLUDING SW NC. LOOKS BORDERLINE FOR FROST 
ADVISORY...BUT WILL GO AHEAD AND ISSUE IN HIGHEST RISK AREAS TO GIVE 
HEADS UP AS SOME LOCATIONS MAY SEE SIGNIFICANT FROST.  WILL INCLUDE 
PATCHY FROST MENTION IN SOME AREAS NEAR FROST ADVISORY.  WILL NOT 
STRAY FAR FROM MAV TEMPS...WHICH LOOK REASONABLE OVERALL.  

.LONG TERM...(THURSDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...HIGH PRESSURE AT
THE SURFACE AND ALOFT OVER THE SOUTHEAST AND TENNESSEE VALLEY WILL
CONTINUE THURSDAY NIGHT AND FRIDAY. DEEP LOW PRESSURE AREA AND
ASSOCIATED UPPER TROUGH NOW OVER THE NORTHWEST PART OF THE COUNTRY
WILL MOVE EAST INTO THE PLAINS STATES AND SOUTH CENTRAL CANADA OVER
THE WEEKEND. SOUTH TO SOUTHWEST FLOW WILL INCREASE FRIDAY RAISING
TEMPERATURES AND MOISTURE WITH HIGHS IN THE 80S. CLOUD COVER WILL
INCREASE FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY AND TEMPERATURES WILL BE VERY
WARM. A NEW AREA OF LOW PRESSURE IS EXPECTED TO DEVELOP IN THE
SOUTHERN PLAINS SATURDAY. THE AIR MASS WILL BECOME UNSTABLE SATURDAY
WITH SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOPING AHEAD OF THE FRONT WHICH
WILL STILL BE OVER THE PLAINS STATES. THE FRONT WILL ONLY MOVE
SLOWLY SOUTHEAST THROUGH THE REMAINDER OF THE EXTENDED AS THE LOW
IN THE SOUTHERN PLAINS MOVES EAST. THERE WILL BE A THREAT FOR SEVERE
THUNDERSTORMS SATURDAY AND SUNDAY WITH A CHANCE OF THUNDERSTORMS
THROUGH MIDWEEK AS THE FRONTAL SYSTEM WILL BE IN THE VICINITY.
TEMPERATURES WILL STAY MILD WITH MOSTLY CLOUDY SKIES FROM LATE
SATURDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY. THERE IS A POTENTIAL FOR HEAVY RAIN
FROM SUNDAY ON AS THUNDERSTORM DEVELOP EACH DAY SO WILL HAVE TO
WATCH THIS AS THE WEEKEND GETS CLOSER.

049 
FXUS64 KMRX 280211
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1000 PM EDT TUE APR 27 2010

.DISCUSSION...UPPER TROF HAS MOVED SE OF AREA. SURFACE HIGH PRESSURE 
BUILDING IN FROM THE NW. DECREASING CLOUD COVER AND SLACKENING WINDS 
WILL ALLOW TEMPS TO FALL THROUGH EARLY DAWN. LOW LEVEL MOISTURE 
SUFFICIENT FOR PATCHY FROST AND FOG. SON

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION:
SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY)...AN UPPER LOW IS MAKING ITS WAY 
ACROSS THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS. ASSOCIATED SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS HAVE SPREAD OVER THE AREA.  WITH COLD AIR ALOFT AND A 
WEAKLY UNSTABLE AIR MASS...A FEW THUNDERSTORMS THAT DEVELOP ACROSS 
THE AREA COULD PRODUCE SMALL HAIL AND GUSTY WINDS.  CONVECTION 
SHOULD END BY SUNSET AS DRY AIR AND HIGH PRESSURE BUILD IN.  COLD 
AIR IS CONTINUING TO FILTER IN AND WILL KEEP TEMPERATURES BELOW 
NORMAL TONIGHT.  LOWS ARE EXPECTED TO DROP INTO THE 30S AT MANY 
LOCATIONS AND A FROST ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR THESE LOCATIONS 
DURING THE OVERNIGHT...EARLY MORNING HOURS.  TUESDAY WILL SEE A 
DRYING AND WARMING TREND AS HIGH PRESSURE ESTABLISHES ITSELF OVER 
THE REGION.

LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY)...RIDGING BOTH SURFACE 
AND ALOFT WILL KEEP DRY AND WARMER CONDITIONS ACROSS THE FORECAST 
AREA THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. DUE TO THE GOOD RADIATIONAL COOLING 
CONDITIONS WEDNESDAY NIGHT...PATCHY FROST WILL ONCE AGAIN BE 
POSSIBLE ACROSS NORTHEAST TENNESSEE AND SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA EARLY 
THURSDAY MORNING.

FOR LATE FRIDAY AND SATURDAY...RIDGING WILL MOVE EAST ALLOWING FOR 
RETURN OF GULF MOISTURE INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY AND SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIANS. A DEEP-BROAD UPPER TROUGH WILL ESTABLISH ITSELF ACROSS 
THE ROCKY'S AND PLAIN STATES FOR SATURDAY AND SUNDAY BEFORE 
BEGINNING TO LIFT OUT AND WEAKEN MONDAY AND TUESDAY. A FRONT WILL 
MOVE INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY THIS WEEKEND. THERE ARE DIFFERENCES 
BETWEEN THE GFS AND ECMWF ON HOW FAR SOUTH THE FRONT GOES BEFORE 
BECOMING STATIONARY. I EXPECT FRONT TO MOVE SLOWLY SOUTH ACROSS THE 
FORECAST AREA THIS WEEKEND THROUGH MONDAY. WILL MAINTAIN A CHANCE OF 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS UNTIL MONDAY...THEN DRYING OUT FROM NORTH 
TO SOUTH.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN  41  70  46  80  54 /  10   0   0   0  10

FXUS64 KMRX 271850
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
249 PM EDT TUE APR 27 2010

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT AND WEDNESDAY)...AN UPPER LOW IS MAKING ITS WAY 
ACROSS THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS. ASSOCIATED SCATTERED SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS HAVE SPREAD OVER THE AREA.  WITH COLD AIR ALOFT AND A 
WEAKLY UNSTABLE AIR MASS...A FEW THUNDERSTORMS THAT DEVELOP ACROSS 
THE AREA COULD PRODUCE SMALL HAIL AND GUSTY WINDS.  CONVECTION 
SHOULD END BY SUNSET AS DRY AIR AND HIGH PRESSURE BUILD IN.  COLD 
AIR IS CONTINUING TO FILTER IN AND WILL KEEP TEMPERATURES BELOW 
NORMAL TONIGHT.  LOWS ARE EXPECTED TO DROP INTO THE 30S AT MANY 
LOCATIONS AND A FROST ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT FOR THESE LOCATIONS 
DURING THE OVERNIGHT...EARLY MORNING HOURS.  TUESDAY WILL SEE A 
DRYING AND WARMING TREND AS HIGH PRESSURE ESTABLISHES ITSELF OVER 
THE REGION.

.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY)...RIDGING BOTH SURFACE 
AND ALOFT WILL KEEP DRY AND WARMER CONDITIONS ACROSS THE FORECAST 
AREA THURSDAY AND FRIDAY. DUE TO THE GOOD RADITIONAL COOLING 
CONDITIONS WEDNESDAY NIGHT...PATCHY FROST WILL ONCE AGAIN BE 
POSSIBLE ACROSS NORTHEAST TENNESSEE AND SOUTHWEST VIRGINIA EARLY 
THURSDAY MORNING.

FOR LATE FRIDAY AND SATURDAY...RIDGING WILL MOVE EAST ALLOWING FOR 
RETURN OF GULF MOISTURE INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY AND SOUTHERN 
APPALACHIANS. A DEEP-BROAD UPPER TROUGH WILL ESTABLISH ITSELF ACROSS 
THE ROCKY'S AND PLAIN STATES FOR SATURDAY AND SUNDAY BEFORE 
BEGINNING TO LIFT OUT AND WEAKEN MONDAY AND TUESDAY. A FRONT WILL 
MOVE INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY THIS WEEKEND. THERE ARE DIFFERENCES 
BETWEEN THE GFS AND ECMWF ON HOW FAR SOUTH THE FRONT GOES BEFORE 
BECOMING STATIONARY. I EXPECT FRONT TO MOVE SLOWLY SOUTH ACROSS THE 
FORECAST AREA THIS WEEKEND THROUGH MONDAY. WILL MAINTAIN A CHANCE OF 
SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS UNTIL MONDAY...THEN DRYING OUT FROM NORTH 
TO SOUTH.

322 
FXUS64 KMRX 270725
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
325 AM EDT TUE APR 27 2010

.SHORT TERM (TODAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT)...THE CLOSED LOW OVER 
MISSOURI THIS MORNING WILL TRANSITION TO AN OPEN WAVE AS IT TRACKS 
SOUTHEAST THROUGH TODAY. THE MODELS SEEM TO HAVE A GOOD HANDLE ON 
THIS SYSTEM...SO WILL GO WITH LIKELY TO CATEGORICAL POPS TODAY. THE 
AREA OF RAIN MOVING INTO MIDDLE TN APPEARS TO BE ASSOCIATED WITH 500 
MB PVA AND 850-700 MB CONVERGENCE...AND WILL REACH OUR AREA AROUND 
12Z. AFTER THIS INITIAL SURGE OF PRECIP THIS MORNING...UPSTREAM 
SATELLITE TRENDS INDICATE SOME CLEARING WILL OCCUR. THE MIDLEVEL 
COLD POOL ALSO MOVES OVER THIS AFTERNOON...ALLOWING FOR SOME 
DESTABILIZATION. NAM AND GFS INDICATE MLCAPE VALUES AROUND 300 
J/KG...LOW LEVEL LAPSE RATES OF 7-8 C/KM...AND TT AROUND 55 C...SO 
WE COULD SEE SOME SCATTERED THUNDERSTORMS TODAY. SOME SMALL HAIL AND 
STRONG WIND GUSTS WILL BE POSSIBLE GIVEN THE STEEP LAPSE RATES AND 
INVERTED-V SOUNDINGS SHOWN BY THE MODELS.

THE PASSAGE OF THE 700 MB TROUGH SHOULD BRING AN END TO ANY SHOWERS 
THIS EVENING...AND FORECAST SOUNDINGS SHOW RAPID DRYING ALOFT AFTER 
MIDNIGHT. A SURFACE RIDGE AXIS QUICKLY BUILDS INTO THE AREA 
TONIGHT...WHICH SHOULD DROP WINDS OFF TO NEAR CALM IN MOST 
LOCATIONS. THIS WILL ALLOW TEMPERATURES TO FALL VERY QUICKLY...INTO 
THE 30S ACROSS MOST OF THE AREA. LOWS IN THE MID 30S APPEAR LIKELY 
ACROSS THE NORTH AND IN THE MOUNTAINS AND PLATEAU...SO A FROST 
ADVISORY WILL BE ISSUED FOR TONIGHT. 

WEDNESDAY THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT WILL FEATURE A HIGH PRESSURE RIDGE 
OVER THE AREA...WITH CLEAR SKIES AND A WARMING TREND EXPECTED. THERE 
COULD BE SOME PATCHY FROST IN SOME AREAS AGAIN WEDNESDAY NIGHT...BUT 
BY THURSDAY HIGH TEMPS WILL BE BACK TO NORMAL...IN THE 70S. 

.LONG TERM (FRIDAY THROUGH MONDAY)...MODELS GENERALLY AGREE THAT 
LONG WAVE RIDGE PRESSES SLOWLY EAST ACROSS THE APPALACHIANS TOWARD 
THE EASTERN SEABOARD ON FRIDAY WITH STRENGTHENING SOUTHWEST FLOW 
ALOFT AS LONG WAVE TROF/UPPER LOW ALSO SHIFTS ONLY SLOWLY EAST 
ACROSS THE NORTH CENTRAL STATES. SEVERAL SHORTER WAVELENGTH FEATURES 
WILL TRAVERSE THE MID MISSISSIPPI AND OHIO VALLEY. THE SOUTHERN 
EXTENT OF THESE FEATURES MAY CLIP THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION 
AND WITH STRENGTHENING LOW LEVEL FLOW SQUEEZED BETWEEN LOWER 
PRESSURE ACROSS THE MISSISSIPPI VALLEY AND A SURFACE RIDGE PARKED 
OVER THE WESTERN ATLANTIC...THE POSSIBILITY OF SHOWERS AND 
THUNDERSTORMS WILL INCREASE ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA FROM THE 
WEEKEND RIGHT THROUGH MONDAY.      

&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
238 PM EDT MON APR 26 2010

.SHORT TERM TONIGHT AND TUESDAY)...AN UPPER LOW IS TRACKING ACROSS 
THE OHIO VALLEY REGION AND WILL CONTINUE TO ROTATE IN LOW CLOUDS AND 
OCCASIONAL LIGHT RAIN SHOWERS INTO THE MRX CWA THROUGH THE SHORT

THUNDERSTORMS DEVELOP OVER THE AREA.  TEMPERATURES WILL AGAIN BE 
COOL WITH HIGHS EXPECTED TO REACH INTO THE UPPER 50S TO MID 60S 
ACROSS THE TN VALLEY.

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY NIGHT MONDAY)...FOR TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH 
THURSDAY A RIDGE OF HIGH PRESSURE WILL BUILD INTO THE FORECAST AREA 
PRODUCING MOSTLY CLEAR SKY AND WARMER TEMPERATURES. SURFACE RIDGING 
WILL ALLOW FOR GOOD RADIATIONAL COOLING CONDITIONS TUESDAY NIGHT AND 
WEDNESDAY NIGHT. SCATTERED FROST IS POSSIBLE FOR AREAS ALONG AND 
NORTH OF KNOXVILLE (INCLUDING SOUTHERN PLATEAU) FOR WEDNESDAY 
MORNING AND NORTHERN VALLEY THURSDAY MORNING.

BY FRIDAY...UPPER AND SURFACE RIDGING WILL PULL EAST ALLOWING FOR 
RETURN OF GULF MOISTURE AHEAD OF A DEEP UPPER TROUGH OVER THE PLAIN 
STATES. WARMER TEMPERATURES AND PARTLY CLOUDY SKIES ANTICIPATED.

FOR SATURDAY THROUGH MONDAY...A PERSISTEN UPPER TROUGH WILL REMAIN 
ACROSS THE ROCKY'S AND PLAINS KEEPING THE TENNESSEE VALLEY AND 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS UNDER SOUTHWEST FLOW ALOFT. WEAK COLD FRONT 
WILL MOVE INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY THEN STALL ACTING AS A FOCUS FOR 
CONVECTION THROUGH THE PERIOD. SERIES OF UPPER WAVES WILL EJECT OUT 
OF THE UPPER TROUGH PRODUCING AREAS OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS. 
TIMING OF THESE WAVES WILL BE DIFFICULT AT BEST. WILL CALL FOR 
CHANCE OF CONVECTION THROUGH THE PERIOD. WILL HAVE TO WATCH FOR THE 
POTENTIAL OF FLOODING AS TRAINING OF STORMS ARE POSSIBLE.

AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
427 AM EDT MON APR 26 2010

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...
CLOSED UPPER LOW WILL SLOWLY TRACK EASTWARD ACROSS THE OHIO VALLEY 
AND CENTRAL APPALACHIANS TODAY AND TONIGHT. MOISTURE WRAPPING AROUND 
THE LOW WILL KEEP CLOUDS IN PLACE THROUGH THE SHORT TERM...WITH 
SCATTERED TO NUMEROUS RAIN SHOWERS. BEST PRECIP CHANCES WILL BE IN 
THE NORTH CLOSER TO THE SYSTEM...AND WILL HAVE LIKELY POPS THERE 
DROPPING DOWN TO CHANCES SOUTH. HOWEVER...PRECIP AMOUNTS WILL BE 
LIGHT AS LIFT REMAINS QUITE WEAK. SHOWERS WILL BE MAINTAINED BY SOME 
INSTABILITY UNDER COOLING MIDLEVEL TEMPS AND CONVERGENCE WITH A WEAK 
850 MB TROUGH. WINDS WILL BE GUSTY AGAIN TODAY...BUT A BIT LIGHTER 
AS THE MIXED LAYER WILL NOT BE AS DEEP DUE TO CLOUD COVER. CLOUDS 
AND WEAK COLD ADVECTION SHOULD KEEP TEMPS FROM RISING MUCH 
TODAY...AS HIGHS WILL ONLY REACH THE LOWER 60S NORTH TO MID 60S 
SOUTH AND 50S IN THE HIGHER ELEVATIONS. 

AS THE LOW MOVES AWAY TONIGHT...A MIDLEVEL RIDGE BUILDS OVER THE 
AREA. FORECAST SOUNDINGS SHOW A DRYING TREND THROUGH THE NIGHT...SO 
WILL BRING POPS DOWN TO A SLIGHT CHANCE/LOW CHANCE AFTER MIDNIGHT. 
ANOTHER MID/UPPER LEVEL TROUGH AND JET STREAK WILL APPROACH FROM THE 
WEST LATE TONIGHT...BUT MOST PRECIP WITH THIS FEATURE SHOULD HOLD 
OFF UNTIL AFTER 12Z TUESDAY.

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...A SHORTWAVE TRACKS THROUGH THE 
AREA ON TUESDAY AND TUESDAY NIGHT. WILL KEEP HIGHEST CHANCES IN THE 
NORTHERN PORTIONS OF THE CWA. HIGH PRESSURE RETURNS BRINGING DRY 
WEATHER FOR WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. A FRONT TRACKS INTO THE AREA BY 
LATE FRIDAY AND LINGERS INTO SUNDAY. WILL KEEP ONLY LOW CHANCE POPS 
GOING FOR NOW. SHOULD SEE A WARMING TREND THROUGH THE PERIOD. STAYED 
NEAR MEX/HPC GUIDANCE FOR TEMPERATURES.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
300 PM EDT SUN APR 25 2010

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE 
ANALYSIS SHOWS A LARGE LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM CENTERED OVER THE MID 
WEST...WITH ITS ASSOCIATED COLD FRONT EXTENDING ACROSS THE 
CAROLINAS. SATELLITE IMAGERY REVEALS AN EXTENSIVE AREA OF CLOUDINESS 
WITH THIS LOW OVER THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY...WITH SOME SCATTERED 
CONVECTION DEVELOPING ALONG THE OHIO RIVER AHEAD OF A SURFACE TROUGH 
ROTATING AROUND THE LOW. MODEL SOUNDINGS REVEAL WEAK INSTABILITY 
DEVELOPING BY LATE AFTERNOON...SO WILL INCLUDE A CHANCE OF TSTORMS 
UNTIL SUNSET. LOWERING WET BULB ZERO HEIGHTS (DUE TO THE COLD TEMPS 
ALOFT WITH THE UPPER LOW) COULD PROMOTE THE DEVELOPMENT OF HAIL WITH 
A FEW STORMS (MAINLY ACROSS THE NORTHERN HALF OF THE FORECAST AREA). 
THIS LARGE LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM IS PROGGED TO SLOWLY MOVE EAST OVER 
THE NEXT 48 HOURS...WITH CLOUDS AND SCATTERED SHOWERS SPREADING OVER 
THE FORECAST AREA THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT. BY TUESDAY...ANOTHER 
SECONDARY UPPER-LEVEL TROUGH IS PROGGED TO SWING ACROSS THE TN RIVER 
VALLEY...GENERATING A BETTER COVERAGE OF CONVECTION. MODEL SOUNDINGS 
REVEAL A MARGINALLY UNSTABLE AIR MASS DEVELOPING OVER THE FORECAST 
AREA...SO WILL PLAN TO INCLUDE A MENTION THUNDER ON TUESDAY. AS FOR 
TEMPS...GFS AND NAM GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE IN GENERAL AGREEMENT 
THROUGH THE PERIOD...BUT WILL TREND TOWARDS THE COOLER GFS NUMBERS 
DUE TO THE EXPECTED CLOUDINESS WITH SCATTERED SHOWERS.

.LONG TERM (WEDNESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN FOR 
QUIET...UNEVENTFUL WEATHER WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. FOR THE END OF 
THE EXTENDED...WILL MOVE INTO AN UNSETTLED WEATHER PATTERN AS A 
SERIES OF SYSTEMS MOVE INTO THE REGION. MODELS IN POOR AGREEMENT ON 
TIMING AND DETAILS SO HAVE ADDED 20 TO 30 POPS FOR FRIDAY SATURDAY 
AND SUNDAY...WITH SOME DRY PERIODS IN PLACE.

.DISCUSSION...

WITH AN EXTENSIVE AREA OF CLOUDINESS NORTH OF THE OHIO RIVER NEAR 
THIS SURFACE LOW. THIS LARGE SYSTEM WILL CONTINUE TO MOVE EAST 
TODAY...WITH THE TIGHT PRESSURE GRADIENT OVER THE FORECAST AREA 
CREATING BREEZY WINDS THIS AFTERNOON. RIGHT NOW...IT APPEARS THAT 
WIND SPEEDS WILL REMAIN JUST BELOW ADVISORY CRITERIA. AS A TROUGH 
ROTATES AROUND THIS LOW...CLOUDS SHOULD SLOWLY INCREASE LATER THIS 
AFTERNOON WITH A CHANCE OF CONVECTION ACROSS THE NORTHWEST HALF OF 
THE FORECAST AREA. MODEL SOUNDINGS REVEAL SOME WEAK INSTABILITY 
DEVELOPING BY LATE AFTERNOON...SO WILL INCLUDE A MENTION OF TSTORMS. 
LOWERING WET BULB ZERO HEIGHTS (DUE TO THE COLD TEMPS ALOFT WITH THE 
UPPER LOW) COULD PROMOTE THE DEVELOPMENT OF SOME HAIL WITH A FEW 
STORMS.

OVERALL...CURRENT FORECAST APPEARS TO BE ON TRACK...BUT WILL PLAN TO 
UPDATE THIS MORNING TO REMOVE MENTION OF MORNING WORDING AND TO TWEAK 
TEMPS A LITTLE ACCORDING TO THE LATEST TRENDS.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1000 AM EDT SAT APR 24 2010

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS A STRONG LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM CENTERED 
OVER THE CENTRAL PLAINS...WITH A QUASI-STATIONARY FRONTAL BOUNDARY 
EXTENDING ALONG A LINE GENERALLY FROM LOUISVILLE KY TO KNOXVILLE TO 
ASHEVILLE NC. AREA RADARS REVEAL SCATTERED CONVECTION RAPIDLY 
INTENSIFYING ACROSS MS AND AL...WHICH WAS MOVING NORTHEAST TOWARDS 
THE FORECAST AREA. LATEST RUC MODEL INDICATES VERY STRONG HELICITY 
VALUES AND MODERATE INSTABILITY DEVELOPING OVER MIDDLE TN BY MID 
AFTERNOON...AND THEN SPREADING EAST INTO THE FORECAST AREA BY LATE 
AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING. RUC MODEL SOUNDINGS INDICATE A CAP 
DEVELOPING IN THE MID LEVELS...BUT IT IS DIFFICULT TO KNOW IF THIS 
CAP WILL BE STRONG ENOUGH TO INHIBIT THE INTENSITY OF THE STORMS ANY 
THIS AFTERNOON. SHORT-RANGE MODELS STILL REVEAL ALOT OF CONVECTIVE 
DEVELOPMENT OVER THE FORECAST AREA THIS AFTERNOON...SO THINK THAT 
THE CURRENT FORECAST WHICH MENTIONS THE POSSIBILITY OF NUMEROUS 
SUPERCELLS STILL APPEARS TO BE ON TRACK. AS A RESULT...THERE STILL 
APPEARS TO BE THE POTENTIAL FOR VERY LARGE HAIL (AROUND GOLFBALL 
SIZE HAIL)...DAMAGING WINDS (IN EXCESS OF 60 MPH)...AND SOME 
ISOLATED TORNADOES (A FEW POSSIBLY STRONG AND LONG LIVED). 

OVERALL...CURRENT FORECAST APPEARS TO BE ON TRACK AND WILL NOT PLAN 
TO UPDATE THIS MORNING.

FXUS64 KMRX 241111

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
710 AM EDT SAT APR 24 2010

.AVIATION...FORMER RAIN SHIELD HAS BECOME MOTLEY FOR NOW AND SO HAVE 
GONE WITH VCTY SHOWERS THIS MORNING AND THEN THUNDER THIS AFTERNOON. 
EXPECT STORMS TO FORM LATE THIS MORNING ALONG CUMBERLAND PLATEAU 
MOVING NORTHEAST-ISH. AS THE WARMING PROGRESSES...SUNBREAKS WILL 
DE-STABILIZE THE ATMOSPHERE AND THE STORMS WILL BECOME STRONG THIS 
AFTERNOON, ESPECIALLY AROUND CHA AND TYS. STORMS WILL TAKE ON 
SUPERCEL CHARACTERISTICS AND MOVE MORE TOWARD THE EAST OR EVEN EAST 
SOUTHEAST AND WILL BE MORE ISOLATED OR WIDELY SCATTERED IN NATURE 
AND SO HAVE GONE WITH VCTS RATHER THAN PRVAILING AT TAF SITES. THIS 
COULD CHANGE, BUT ADDED VRB WINDS TO ACCOUNT FOR UNPREDICTABLE 
DIRECTION/SPEED ASSTD WITH STORMS. ALSO...THESE STORMS ARE LIKELY TO 
PRODUCE VERY LARGE HAIL, FREQUENT TO CONTINUOUS LIGHTNING AND 
ISOLATED TORNADOES THROUGH EVENING AT CHA AND TYS. WEAKER BUT STILL 
CAUTIONARY AT TRI AND LATER INTO EVENING. 


&&

.MRX WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
NC...NONE.
TN...NONE.
VA...NONE.

&&

$$

BB


363 
FXUS64 KMRX 240720
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
320 AM EDT SAT APR 24 2010

.SHORT TERM (TODAY AND TONIGHT)...LARGE RAIN SHIELD ASSOCIATED WITH 
FRONTAL SYSTEM APPROACHING FROM THE WEST. SFC WIND FIELD IS A BIT 
DISORGANIZED. THE GULF IS STILL OPEN ALOFT AND SO MUCH OF THE 
CURRENT "FUEL" MOISTURE IS ABOVE THE SURFACE. DEWPOINTS HAVE 
INCREASED INTO THE 60S, THOUGH, SINCE YESTERDAY, AND TEMPS ARE DOWN, 
SO THAT RH'S ARE QUITE HIGH. WITH RELATIVELY STABLE AIRMASS OVER 
EAST SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS ATTM, CURRENT PRECIP IS STRATIFORM AND 
W/O THUNDER. 

THERE SHOULD BE A BREAK IN THE CONVECTIVE ACTION AFTER SUNRISE WITH 
THE LOCAL AIR MASS LIKELY DESTABILIZING FOR ANOTHER ROUND OF 
CONVECTION IN THE AFTERNOON AND EVENING. MODELS AGREE ON AN 
ORGANIZED WIND FIELD DEVELOPING BY THE AFTERNOON INTO THE EVENING, 
WITH MODERATE TO STRONG HELICITY VALUES. THIS WILL CREATE A 
POTENTIAL FOR LONG LIVED UPDRAFTS. MODERATE CAPE AND LI'S WILL ALSO 
ALLOW FOR STRONG UVV IN STORMS. IT WILL BE CRITICAL TO WATCH FOR SFC 
BOUNDARIES FROM OLD STORMS AS THIS WILL INCREASE HELICITY VALUES 
EVEN FURTHER ON A LOCAL BASIS. DUE TO THE PROLONGED NATURE OF THE 
FORECAST UPDRAFTS, EXPECT THAT VERY LARGE HAIL WILL BE LIKELY, THAT 
IS GOLF BALL OR LARGER. ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS MAY ALSO PRODUCE 
TORNADOES AND HAIL UP TO BASEBALL SIZE, ESPECIALLY ALONG THE 
CUMBERLAND PLATEAU AND IN THE SOUTHERN PORTIONS OF THE AREA, WHERE 
TEMPERATURES WILL BE WARMER, PW'S HIGHER AND CONVECTIVE TEMPS ONLY 
IN THE UPPER 70S. TIMING WILL BE CRITICAL SO THAT ANY BREAKS IN THE 
CLOUDS AND PRECIP (AND THE RAIN SHIELD IS ALREADY BECOMING BLOTCHY 
AT THIS WRITING) WILL PERMIT RAPID WARMING ON A LOCAL BASIS. SOME 
FLOODING RAINS MAY OCCUR, BUT STEERING WINDS APPEAR FAIRLY STRONG 
AND SO MOST STORMS WILL MOVE QUICKLY. HOWEVER, ANY STORMS DEVELOPING 
ALONG QUASI-STATIONARY BOUNDARIES WILL BE SLOW MOVING AND MAY 
PRODUCE FLASH FLOODING OR URBAN/SMALL STREAM FLOODING IN SMALL 
AREAS. 

EXPECT CONVECTION TO CONTINUE PAST SUNSET AND SLOWLY DIE DOWN 
THROUGH THE NIGHT. HAVE KEPT POPS IN THE CHANCE CATEGORY UNTIL 
SUNRISE SUNDAY. LARGELY LEFT TEMPS, WINDS, ETC ALONE.


.LONG TERM (SUNDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...UPPER LOW TRACKS THROUGH THE 
AREA ON SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY...WILL GO FOR CHANCE POPS WITH THE 
HIGHEST CHANCES OUR THE NORTHERN ZONES WHERE THE DEEPEST MOISTURE IS 
INDICATED. HIGH PRESSURE RETURNS BRINGING DRY WEATHER FOR WEDNESDAY  
THROUGH FRIDAY. STAYED NEAR MEX/HPC GUIDANCE FOR TEMPERATURES. 


&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             76  60  81  57  68 /  90  90  30  40  40 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  75  60  80  55  65 /  80  90  40  50  50 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       74  60  79  55  65 /  80  90  40  50  50

907 
FXUS64 KMRX 231851
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
250 PM EDT FRI APR 23 2010

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY NIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE 
ANALYSIS SHOWS A WEST-TO-EAST ORIENTED QUASI-STATIONARY FRONTAL 
BOUNDARY OVER CENTRAL KY AND SOUTHWEST VA...WITH RADARS REVEALING 
SOME SCATTERED SHOWERS OCCURRING ALONG AND AHEAD OF IT. THE LOCAL 
AIR MASS IS PROGGED TO REMAIN FAIRLY DRY IN THE LOWER LEVELS THIS 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING...BUT SOME ISOLATED CONVECTION STILL MAY BE 
POSSIBLE INTO THE EVENING HOURS. A STRONG LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM OVER 
THE CENTRAL PLAINS IS PROGGED TO TRIGGER A LARGE AREA OF CONVECTION 
OVER THE MS RIVER VALLEY LATER BY THIS EVENING...WHICH THE GFS MODEL 
INDICATES WILL MOVE EAST ACROSS THE TN RIVER VALLEY TONIGHT. THIS 
CONVECTIVE COMPLEX SHOULD WEAKEN AS IT MOVES INTO THE FORECAST AREA 
AFTER MIDNIGHT...BUT THINK THAT A FEW ISOLATED SEVERE STORMS WITH 
DAMAGING WINDS AND LARGE HAIL WILL BE POSSIBLE DURING THE OVERNIGHT 
AND EARLY MORNING HOURS ON SATURDAY. THERE SHOULD BE A BREAK IN THE 
CONVECTIVE ACTION AFTER SUNRISE ON SATURDAY...WITH THE LOCAL AIR 
MASS LIKELY DESTABILIZING FOR ANOTHER ROUND OF CONVECTION IN THE 
AFTERNOON AND EVENING. MODEL SOUNDINGS REVEAL A STRONG WIND FIELD 
DEVELOPING OVER THE TN RIVER VALLEY BY LATE SATURDAY AFTERNOON... 
AHEAD OF AN APPROACHING COLD FRONT. VERY STRONG HELICITY VALUES 
(ESPECIALLY IN THE LOWER LEVELS OVER THE CUMBERLAND PLATEAU BY 
SUNSET) COMBINED WITH STRONG UPPER-LEVEL DYNAMICS WILL LIKELY 
PRODUCE SUPERCELLS ACROSS THE TN RIVER VALLEY...WITH THE POTENTIAL 
FOR EXTREMELY LARGE HAIL (AROUND GOLFBALL SIZE HAIL) AND SOME 
ISOLATED TORNADOES (A FEW POSSIBLY STRONG AND LONG LIVED). SOME 
COMPLICATING FACTORS WHICH COULD AFFECT THE SEVERITY OF THE EVENT 
INCLUDE THE FACT THAT THE MODELS STILL INDICATE THAT THE BEST 
INSTABILITY WILL NOT DEVELOP OVER THE FORECAST AREA UNTIL THE 
EVENING HOURS (WITH ONLY A WEAKLY UNSTABLE ENVIRONMENT ON SATURDAY 
AFTERNOON). HOWEVER...THINK THAT THE CONVECTIVE PARAMETERIZATION 
SCHEMES OF THE MODELS MAY BE PRODUCING UNREALISTIC THERMAL PROFILES 
ON THE SOUNDINGS FOR SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING DUE TO THE 
EARLIER CONVECTION DURING THE MORNING HOURS. ANOTHER 'FLY IN THE 
OINTMENT' INVOLVES THE POSSIBILITY THAT A CONVECTIVE COMPLEX COULD 
INTENSIFY FURTHER SOUTH AND CUT OFF THE BEST MOISTURE SUPPLY TO THE 
FORECAST AREA. DESPITE THESE POSSIBLE CONVECTIVE TIMING ISSUES... 
SEVERE WX PARAMETERS INDICATE THAT THE POTENTIAL WILL EXIST FOR AN 
OUTBREAK OF SEVERE WEATHER ACROSS THE TN RIVER VALLEY...WHICH WILL 
EXTEND INTO THE FORECAST AREA (ESPECIALLY ACROSS THE WESTERN HALF). 
SCATTERED CONVECTION SHOULD AGAIN DEVELOP ON SUNDAY AFTERNOON AND 
EVENING...AS AN UPPER-LEVEL TROUGH SWINGS ACROSS THE TN RIVER 
VALLEY. AS FOR TEMPS...GFS AND NAM GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE IN GENERAL 
AGREEMENT THROUGH THE PERIOD AND LOOK REASONABLE.

.LONG TERM (MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...AN UPPER LOW WILL TRACK THROUGH 
TO OUR NORTH EARLY IN THE PERIOD. THIS WILL ROTATE THROUGH A SERIES 
OF IMPULSES WHICH WILL BRING OCCASIONAL RAIN SHOWERS TO THE AREA 
MONDAY AND TUESDAY. WILL BE BETWEEN SYSTEMS AND HAVE A RETURN TO DRY 
WEATHER WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. MODELS IN POOR AGREEMENT REGARDING 
THE NEXT SYSTEM PROGGED INTO THE REGION AROUND THE FRIDAY TIME 
FRAME. CONFIDENCE LOW...BUT FOR NOW...WILL LEAVE THINGS DRY ON 
FRIDAY.
&&

FXUS64 KMRX 221851
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
250 PM EDT THU APR 22 2010

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH SATURDAY NIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE 
ANALYSIS SHOWS A WEAK COLD FRONT OVER THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY...WITH A 
WARM FRONT EXTENDING FROM THE OZARKS REGION SOUTHEAST TO SOUTHERN 
MIDDLE TN. THIS WARM FRONT IS PROGGED TO BECOME BETTER DEFINED OVER 
THE FORECAST AREA LATER TONIGHT...AS SOUTHERLY WINDS STRENGTHEN 
AHEAD OF A STRONG LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM OVER THE CENTRAL ROCKIES. THIS 
WARM FRONT SHOULD TRIGGER SOME SCATTERED CONVECTION ACROSS THE 
SOUTHERN HALF OF THE FORECAST AREA LATER TONIGHT AND FRIDAY 
MORNING...WITH ITS CONVECTION MAINLY AFFECTING THE NORTHERN HALF OF 
THE FORECAST AREA BY FRIDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING. GFS MODEL 
INDICATES THAT AN UPPER-LEVEL SHORT WAVE WILL AFFECT THE FORECAST 
AREA LATER FRIDAY NIGHT AFTER MIDNIGHT INTO SATURDAY MORNING...WITH 
SCATTERED CONVECTION ONCE AGAIN DEVELOPING. ON SATURDAY...MODELS 
HAVE COME INTO BETTER AGREEMENT WITH THE TIMING OF THE STRONG SYSTEM 
EXPECTED TO AFFECT THE TN RIVER VALLEY BY THE AFTERNOON AND EVENING 
HOURS. MODEL SOUNDINGS REVEAL A STRONG WIND FIELD DEVELOPING OVER 
THE TN RIVER VALLEY ON SATURDAY AFTERNOON...AHEAD OF AN APPROACHING 
COLD FRONT. STRONG HELICITY VALUES (ESPECIALLY IN THE LOWER-LEVELS 
BY SATURDAY EVENING) COMBINED WITH STRONG UPPER-LEVEL DYNAMICS WILL 
LIKELY PRODUCE SUPERCELLS ACROSS THE TN RIVER VALLEY WITH A GOOD 
POTENTIAL FOR EXTREMELY LARGE HAIL AND SOME ISOLATED TORNADOES. 
MODELS HAVE BEEN INCONSISTENT WITH THE AMOUNT OF INSTABILITY WITH 
THIS SYSTEM (BY REVEALING ONLY A MARGINALLY UNSTABLE TO POSSIBLY 
STABLE ENVIRONMENT ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA)...BUT THINK THAT THE 
CONVECTIVE PARAMETERIZATION SCHEMES OF THE MODELS MAY BE PRODUCING 
UNREALISTIC THERMAL PROFILES ON THE SOUNDINGS FOR SATURDAY AFTERNOON 
AND EVENING DUE TO THE EARLIER CONVECTION DURING THE MORNING HOURS. 
IF THE CURRENT TIMING SCENARIO OF CONVECTION AFFECTING THE FORECAST 
AREA DURING THE AFTERNOON AND EVENING HOURS HOLDS TRUE...THEN EXPECT 
THE POTENTIAL FOR AN OUTBREAK OF SEVERE WEATHER ACROSS THE FORECAST 
AREA. AS FOR TEMPS...GFS AND NAM GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE IN GENERAL 
AGREEMENT THROUGH THE PERIOD...BUT WILL COMPROMISE BETWEEN THE TWO 
ON SATURDAY WHEN DIFFERENCES ARE NOTED.

.LONG TERM (SUNDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...WILL BE IN AN UNSETTLED 
WEATHER PATTERN FOR THE FIRST HALF OF THE EXTENDED...AS AN UPPER LOW 
TO OUR NORTH ROTATES THROUGH A SERIES OF WEAK WAVES. THIS WILL KEEP 
A CHANCE OF SHOWERS OVER THE AREA SUNDAY AND MONDAY. ANOTHER SYSTEM 
SLIDES THROUGH LATE TUESDAY. THEN...A RETURN TO DRY CONDITIONS IS 
EXPECTED LATE IN THE PERIOD WITH HIGH PRESSURE BUILDING IN FOR 
WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY. AS FOR TEMPERATURES...GUIDANCE NUMBERS LOOK 
GOOD AND STAYED CLOSE.

.DISCUSSION...
CURRENT SURFACE ANALYSIS SHOWS A WEAK COLD FRONT OVER THE OHIO RIVER 
VALLEY...WITH A WARM FRONT ACROSS THE CENTRAL PLAINS EXTENDING 
SOUTHEAST INTO THE OZARKS AND MID SOUTH REGION. AREA RADARS REVEAL 
SOME ISOLATED SHOWERS OCCURRING AHEAD OF THIS WARM FRONT OVER MIDDLE 
TN...WHICH WERE MOVING SOUTHEAST TOWARDS THE FORECAST AREA. MODEL 
SOUNDINGS REVEAL A VERY DRY BOUNDARY LAYER ACROSS THE FORECAST 
AREA...WHICH WILL LIKELY CAUSE MOST OF THIS RAIN TO EVAPORATE BEFORE 
REACHING THE GROUND. HOWEVER...MODELS HINT AT THE POSSIBILITY OF 
SOME LIGHT PRECIP AMOUNTS THIS AFTERNOON...AS ISENTROPIC LIFT 
INCREASES WITH THE WARM FRONTAL BOUNDARY BECOMING BETTER DEFINED 
NEAR THE FORECAST AREA. THUS...WOULD FEEL MORE COMFORTABLE WITH A 
SLIGHT CHANCE POP IN THE FORECAST FOR THIS AFTERNOON. 

OVERALL...CURRENT FORECAST LOOKS TO BE ON TRACK...BUT WILL PLAN TO 
UPDATE THIS MORNING TO MENTION ISOLATED SHOWERS AND TO TWEAK TEMPS A 
LITTLE ACCORDING TO THE LATEST TRENDS.
&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
321 AM EDT THU APR 22 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...MODELS AND SREF ARE IN GENERAL 
AGREEMENT THAT WEAK ISENTROPIC LIFT WILL ACCOMPANY WARM FRONT AS IT 
APPROACHES THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION LATER TODAY. AT THIS 
TIME...ANTICIPATE ONLY AN INCREASE IN MID-LEVEL CLOUDS AS LOWER 
LEVELS REMAIN QUITE DRY. THUS HAVE OPTED TO GO DRY IN THE FIRST 
PERIOD WITH POPS MORE IN LINE WITH GUIDANCE. MID-LEVEL MOISTURE 
INCREASES SOMEWHAT TONIGHT ALONG WITH SLOW INCREASE IN LOW-LEVEL 
MOISTURE AND SLIGHTLY STRONGER LIFT. CONTINUED SLIGHT CHANCE POPS 
ACROSS THE ENTIRE FORECAST AREA ALTHOUGH EVENT APPEARS RATHER 
INSIGNIFICANT AT THIS TIME. FOR TEMPS...GENERALLY DID NOT DEVIATE 
MUCH FROM MAV GUIDANCE.


.LONG TERM...(FRIDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...MODELS CONTINUE TO BE 
GENERALLY CONSISTENT AND SHOW CONTINUITY TOWARD SIGNIFICANT RAINS 
OVER THE WEEKEND...WITH POTENTIAL FOR STRONG THUNDERSTORMS ON 
SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING. THE DEEPENING UPPER LOW...INFLUX OF 
GULF MOISTURE AND INCREASING LOW LEVEL AND WINDS ALOFT...CONTINUE TO 
SUPPORT LIKELY OR HIGHER POPS FOR SATURDAY INTO EARLY SUNDAY. 

AHEAD OF THIS SYSTEM...COVERAGE OF ANY CONVECTION ON FRIDAY AND 
FRIDAY NIGHT LOOKS TO BE SCATTERED OR LESS...ESPECIALLY ACROSS 
EXTREME SRN AREAS (CHA VICINTY TO CHEROKEE/CLAY COUNTIES). MADE A 
FEW POP ADJUSTMENTS FOR THOSE PERIODS...AND INCREASED QPF AMOUNTS ON 
SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT. ALSO LOWERED MAX TEMPS SLIGHTLY ON THE 
WEEKEND INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK...DUE TO COOLER AIR AND LINGERING 
SHOWERS ON THE BACK SIDE OF THE DEPARTING UPPER LOW. KEPT WEDNESDAY 
DRY FOR NOW AS SURFACE RIDGE SETTLES ACROSS THE REGION...AND HEIGHTS 
RISE ALOFT AS UPPER RIDGE TO THE WEST BUILDS EASTWARD.

WILL STRENGTHEN THUNDERSTORM WORDING WITH SOME LOCALLY HEAVY RAINS 
POSSIBLE THIS WEEKEND IN OUR HAZARDOUS WEATHER OUTLOOK.

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
240 PM EDT WED APR 21 2010

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH FRIDAY NIGHT)...CURRENT SURFACE 
ANALYSIS SHOWS AN ELONGATED AND WEAK AREA OF LOW PRESSURE EXTENDING 
ALONG THE EASTERN SEABOARD...WITH HIGH PRESSURE CENTERED ALONG THE 
GULF COAST. A WEAK COLD FRONT OVER THE MID WEST IS PROGGED TO MOVE 
SOUTH INTO THE OHIO RIVER VALLEY BY SUNRISE ON THURSDAY MORNING... 
BUT THEN BECOME QUASI-STATIONARY NORTH OF THE FORECAST AREA AS THE 
UPPER-LEVEL FLOW BECOMES MORE ZONAL. A WARM FRONT IS ALSO PROGGED TO 
DEVELOP ACROSS THE DEEP SOUTH BY THURSDAY AFTERNOON...AS SOUTHERLY 
WINDS STRENGTHEN AHEAD OF A DEEPENING LOW PRESSURE SYSTEM OVER THE 
CENTRAL PLAINS. WITH THE FORECAST AREA CAUGHT IN THE MIDDLE OF THESE 
TWO FRONTAL BOUNDARIES...WILL PLAN TO MENTION A SLIGHT CHANCE FOR 
SHOWERS ON THURSDAY AFTERNOON. THE WARM FRONT OVER THE DEEP SOUTH IS 
EXPECTED TO MOVE NORTH ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA ON FRIDAY...SO WILL 
MENTION HIGHER CHANCE POPS AND SOME THUNDER SINCE THE MODEL 
SOUNDINGS REVEAL SOME MARGINAL INSTABILITY. AS FOR TEMPS...GFS AND 
NAM GUIDANCE NUMBERS ARE IN GENERAL AGREEMENT THROUGH THURSDAY NIGHT 
AND LOOK REASONABLE. WILL PLAN TO COMPROMISE BETWEEN THE TWO FOR 
FRIDAY AND FRIDAY NIGHT. 

.LONG TERM (SATURDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY)...MODELS SIMILAR SATURDAY 
BUT BEGIN TO DIVERGE BY SUNDAY. STAYED A LITTLE CLOSER TO ECMWF 
DEPICTION THROUGH THE FORECAST PERIOD. AMPLIFIED UPPER PATTERN 
DEVELOPS BY SATURDAY WITH UPPER TROF APPROACHING THROUGH THE PLAINS. 
NICE INFLUX OF MOISTURE FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO AND HEALTHY UPPER 
LEVEL JET WILL LEAD TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS 
SATURDAY AND SATURDAY NIGHT WITH THE BEST CHANCE FOR PRECIP SATURDAY 
NIGHT IN ADVANCE OF SYSTEM COOL FRONT. MEDIUM TO HIGHER CHANCE POP 
LEFT IN PLACE FOR SUNDAY AS FRONT MAKES ITS WAY ACROSS THE 
APPALACHIANS. UPPER LEVEL TROFINESS WILL HANG AROUND THE GREAT LAKES 
THROUGH TUESDAY WITH SEVERAL PIECES OF ENERGY ROTATING SOUTHEAST 
THROUGH THE TROUGH CIRCULATION ACROSS THE SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS. 
THEREFORE HELD ONTO LOW CHANCE POPS THROUGH TUESDAY FOR POSSIBLE 
SHOWERS. THE FORECAST AREA FINALLY WAVES GOODBYE TO THE LONG WAVE 
TROUGH AS IT EXITS ACROSS THE EASTERN SEABOARD TUESDAY NIGHT INTO 
WEDNESDAY. BUILDING HEIGHTS WILL ALLOW FOR THE POSSIBILITY OF A DRY 
WEDNESDAY. STAYED FAIRLY CLOSE TO SUGGESTED MEX MOS GUIDANCE TEMPS 
ALTHOUGH EDGED THE NUMBERS SLIGHTLY HIGHER MONDAY THROUGH WEDNESDAY.

908 
FXUS64 KMRX 201343
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
943 AM EDT TUE APR 20 2010

.DISCUSSION...RADAR INDICATING LIGHT RAIN MOVING UP FROM THE SOUTH 
ASSOCIATED A SHORTWAVE TRACKING THROUGH THE AREA. CURRENT POPS AND 
THE REST OF THE FORECAST ON TRACK. WILL UPDATE ZONES TO REMOVE 
MORNING WORDING. NO OTHER CHANGES PLANNED.

.PREVIOUS DISCUSSION... 

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...SHORTWAVE TROUGH OVER THE MID 
MISSISSIPPI VALLEY REGION IS APPROACHING...WITH WEAK ISENTROPIC LIFT 
PRODUCING MAINLY A LOWERING CLOUD DECK THUS FAR (EXCEPT FOR PERHAPS 
A FEW SPRINKLES OVER SE TN). NEXT BATCH OF ECHOES ON AREA RADARS 
SHOULD START TO REACH THE SURFACE. THIS SYSTEM SEEMS TO BE 
DEVELOPING IN LINE WITH SHORT RANGE MODELS...AND THE ENSEMBLES ALSO 
SUPPORT LIKELY TO CATEGORICAL POPS FOR TODAY. THUS...KEPT POP AND 
WEATHER GRIDS RIGHT IN LINE WITH PREVIOUS GRIDS...WITH A GROWING 
AREA OF LIGHT RAIN/SHOWERS BY 12Z TO 18Z. DON'T SEE AMOUNTS AS VERY 
SIGNIFICANT...PROBABLY 1/4 INCH OR LESS TOTAL. THIS PRECIPITATION 
SHOULD BE MOVING NE OUT THE AREA BEFORE DAYBREAK WEDNESDAY...WITH 
CLOUDS DECREASING LATE. 

20/00Z MOS WAS A BIT WARMER ON MAX TEMPS FOR TODAY...BUT I STAYED 
JUST A DEGREE OR SO BELOW GFS MOS SINCE CLOUDS AND RAIN CHANCES BOTH 
INCREASE. MOS GUIDANCE ON MINS WAS VERY CLOSE AND FOLLOWED.


.LONG TERM...(WEDNESDAY THROUGH MONDAY)...UNSETTLED WEATHER EXPECTED 
TO CONTINUE THROUGH THE LONG TERM AS A SERIES OF SYSTEMS AFFECTS THE 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION BY THE WEEKEND PER MODEL AND ENSEMBLE 
CONSENSUS. POOR AGREEMENT AMONG MODELS AND WIDE SPREADS AMONG 
ENSEMBLE MEMBERS LEAD TO A CONTINUATION OF LOW CONFIDENCE HOWEVER. 
THUS CONTINUED WITH CHANCE POPS SPREAD OVER SEVERAL PERIODS TO 
ACCOUNT FOR TIMING DISCREPANCIES. OTHERWISE...DRY PERIOD EXPECTED 
FROM MID TO LATE WEEK. FOR TEMPS...GENERALLY MADE ONLY SLIGHT TWEAKS

FXUS64 KMRX 200737
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
337 AM EDT TUE APR 20 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...SHORTWAVE TROUGH OVER THE MID 
MISSISSIPPI VALLEY REGION IS APPROACHING...WITH WEAK ISENTROPIC LIFT 
PRODUCING MAINLY A LOWERING CLOUD DECK THUS FAR (EXCEPT FOR PERHAPS 
A FEW SPRINKLES OVER SE TN). NEXT BATCH OF ECHOES ON AREA RADARS 
SHOULD START TO REACH THE SURFACE. THIS SYSTEM SEEMS TO BE 
DEVELOPING IN LINE WITH SHORT RANGE MODELS...AND THE ENSEMBLES ALSO 
SUPPORT LIKELY TO CATEGORICAL POPS FOR TODAY. THUS...KEPT POP AND 
WEATHER GRIDS RIGHT IN LINE WITH PREVIOUS GRIDS...WITH A GROWING 
AREA OF LIGHT RAIN/SHOWERS BY 12Z TO 18Z. DON'T SEE AMOUNTS AS VERY 
SIGNIFICANT...PROBABLY 1/4 INCH OR LESS TOTAL. THIS PRECIPITATION 
SHOULD BE MOVING NE OUT THE AREA BEFORE DAYBREAK WEDNESDAY...WITH 
CLOUDS DECREASING LATE. 

20/00Z MOS WAS A BIT WARMER ON MAX TEMPS FOR TODAY...BUT I STAYED 
JUST A DEGREE OR SO BELOW GFS MOS SINCE CLOUDS AND RAIN CHANCES BOTH 
INCREASE. MOS GUIDANCE ON MINS WAS VERY CLOSE AND FOLLOWED.


.LONG TERM...(WEDNESDAY THROUGH MONDAY)...UNSETTLED WEATHER EXPECTED 
TO CONTINUE THROUGH THE LONG TERM AS A SERIES OF SYSTEMS AFFECTS THE 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN REGION BY THE WEEKEND PER MODEL AND ENSEMBLE 
CONSENSUS. POOR AGREEMENT AMONG MODELS AND WIDE SPREADS AMONG 
ENSEMBLE MEMBERS LEAD TO A CONTINUATION OF LOW CONFIDENCE HOWEVER. 
THUS CONTINUED WITH CHANCE POPS SPREAD OVER SEVERAL PERIODS TO 
ACCOUNT FOR TIMING DISCREPANCIES. OTHERWISE...DRY PERIOD EXPECTED 
FROM MID TO LATE WEEK. FOR TEMPS...GENERALLY MADE ONLY SLIGHT TWEAKS 
TO PRECEDING GRIDS BASED ON LATEST MAV/MEX GUIDANCE AND ENSEMBLE 
TRENDS.

AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
307 PM EDT MON APR 19 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY NIGHT)...AN INVERTED TROUGH 
TRACKING THROUGH TONIGHT AND TUESDAY.  LIGHT RAIN SHOULD BE MOVING 
UP FROM THE SOUTH TONIGHT...BUT THE BULK OF THE PRECIPITATION SHOULD 
HOLD OFF UNTIL LATE AND INTO TUESDAY.  WILL KEEP HIGHEST CHANCE IN 
THE SOUTH TONIGHT.  WILL BUMP UP POPS AND GO WITH LIKELY CHANCES FOR 
TUESDAY.  THE TROUGH EXITS THE AREA ON TUESDAY NIGHT...WILL KEEP THE 
HIGHEST CHANCES FOR THE EVENING HOURS.  GUIDANCE NUMBER FOR 
TEMPERATURES SIMILAR SO DIDN'T STRAY TOO FAR. 

.LONG TERM...(WEDNESDAY THROUGH MONDAY)...UNCERTAINTY HIGHER THAN 
AVERAGE FOR THE LONG TERM.  EARLY IN PERIOD BROAD TROUGH OVER 
EASTERN US WITH POSSIBILITY OF SOME WEAK SHORT WAVE ENERGY MOVING 
THROUGH IN THE NORTHWEST FLOW.  HOWEVER...GIVEN POOR AGREEMENT ON 
ANY FEATURE AND EXPECTED WEAKNESS OF ANY WAVES FOR NOW WILL GO 
CLOSER TO BOTH SREF AND PERSISTENCE AND KEEP WED AND THU DRY OTHER 
THAN A FEW LINGERING SHOWERS NORTHEAST EARLY WED.  FURTHER 
OUT...SIGNIFICANT  MODEL DIFFERENCES FOR MORE SIGNIFICANT WEEKEND 
SYSTEM. FAIRLY HIGH CONFIDENCE OF SOME SIGNIFICANT PRECIP DURING THE 
WEEKEND...BUT TIMING UNCERTAINTIES WILL LEAD TO LONGER PERIOD OF 
MAINLY CHANCE POPS RATHER THAN HIGHER POPS FOR FEWER PERIODS.  WILL 
KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE POPS FOR MONDAY AS MODELS HINT A WEAKER WAVE MAY 
AFFECT THE AREA DURING THAT TIME FRAME.  WILL GENERALLY NOW STRAY 
FAR FROM GFS MOS TEMPS.

FXUS64 KMRX 191328
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
928 AM EDT MON APR 19 2010

.DISCUSSION...WITH TEMPERATURES CURRENTLY IN THE UPPER 30S TO THE 
40S...UPDATED FORECAST TO REMOVE FROST ADVISORY AND TO REMOVE THE  
MORNING WORDING. NO OTHER CHANGES MADE AT THIS TIME. 

.PREVIOUS DISCUSSION...

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT WILL GIVE 
WAY TO RIDGING AHEAD OF A WEAK SHORTWAVE TROUGH. SURFACE RIDGE 
CENTERED OVER GREAT LAKES WILL PROVIDE DRY WEATHER UNDER MOSTLY 
SUNNY SKIES TODAY. SURFACE LOW PRESSURE WILL DEVELOP ACROSS GULF 
COAST STATES WITH AN INVERTED SURFACE TROUGH EXTENDING NE INTO THE 
SOUTHERN APPALACHIANS BY 12Z TUESDAY. WEAK ISENTROPIC LIFT MAY LEAD 
TO A FEW SHOWERS LATE TONIGHT...BUT FOLLOWED A BLEND OF MOS 
POPS...WHICH WAS IN LINE WITH PREVIOUS GRIDS AND ADJACENT OFFICES 
GRIDS.

OTHERWISE...FROST ADVISORY WILL RUN THROUGH 9AM EDT TODAY...WITH 
CURRENT TEMPS IN THE 30S WHERE LIGHTEST WINDS WERE NOTED. MAX TEMPS 
SHOULD REACH JUST BELOW SEASONAL NORMS THIS AFTERNOON...THEN MILDER 
MINS TONIGHT AS CLOUDS INCREASE.

.LONG TERM...(TUESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY)...INVERTED TROUGH OVER THE TN
VALLEY AND LOW PRESSURE OVER THE FL PANHANDLE TUESDAY MORNING WILL
CAUSE SCATTERED SHOWERS ACROSS THE FORECAST AREA. THIS SYSTEM WILL
MOVE SLOWLY EAST AND INTO THE CAROLINAS BY WEDNESDAY MORNING. HAVE
INCREASED POPS TUESDAY AND TUESDAY NIGHT. WEDNESDAY CONDITIONS
IMPROVE AS WEAK HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS ACROSS THE REGION. ONLY LOW
POPS NE SECTIONS. GFS SHOWS ANOTHER SYSTEM IN NW FLOW WEDNESDAY AND
NAM WEDNESDAY NIGHT. ECMWF DRIER MODEL SO FOR NOW KEEP PRECIPITATION
OUT OF THE FORECAST. NEXT SYSTEM DEVELOPING OVER THE PLAINS WILL
BRING SHOWERS AND THUNDERSTORMS TO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY FRIDAY
THROUGH SUNDAY.  


&&

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
320 PM EDT SUN APR 18 2010

.SHORT TERM (TONIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY)...LIGHT WINDS AND CLEAR SKIES 
OVERNIGHT WILL ALLOW TEMPS TO FALL HARD OVERNIGHT. DEW POINTS ARE IN 
THE 20S. FROST WILL DEVELOP LATE ACROSS THE ADVISORY AREA AND SHOULD 
BE OF RELATIVELY SHORT DURATION. WEAK FLOW MONDAY WITH NEUTRAL TEMP 
ADVECTION. DAY TIME HEATING WILL ALLOW TEMPS TO WARM NICELY BY THE 
AFTERNOON. SHORT WAVE MOVES EAST INTO THE TN RVR VLY MONDAY NIGHT. 
ISENTROPIC LIFT DEVELOPS OVER SOUTHERN PARTS OF THE AREA LATE. 
CLOUDS WILL INCREASE AND LIGHT RAIN MOVES IN BY TUE MORNING. TEMPS 
MUCH WARMER. SHORT WAVE MOVES INTO THE AREA ON TUE. COOL AND CLOUDY 
WITH LIGHT PCPN ADVANCING ACROSS THE ENTIRE MRX CWA. RAINFALL 
AMOUNTS WILL BE PALTRY.   

.LONG TERM (TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH SUNDAY)...THE TROUGH LINGERS INTO 
EARLY TUESDAY NIGHT SO WILL CONTINUE WITH THE HIGHEST CHANCES FOR 
THE EVENING HOURS. HIGH PRESSURE RETURNS BRINGING DRY WEATHER FOR 
WEDNESDAY AND THURSDAY.  ANOTHER FRONT APPROACHES LATE FRIDAY AND 
LINGERS INTO SATURDAY. WITH PLENTY OF MOISTURE EXPECTED...WILL BUMP 
UP POPS FOR FRIDAY NIGHT AND SATURDAY. THE FRONT LINGERS INTO EARLY 
SUNDAY SO WILL ADD CHANCE POPS SUNDAY. STAYED NEAR MEX/HPC GUIDANCE 
FOR TEMPERATURES.

120 
FXUS64 KMRX 180841 CCA
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
433 AM EDT SUN APR 18 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...LIGHT NORTHERLY WINDS OVERNIGHT 
HAVE BEEN KEEPING TEMPS UP FROM GRID VALUES...IN MOST AREAS. SUCH 
THAT AREAS OF FROST LOOK TO BE LIMITED THIS MORNING...SO A FEW AREAS 
WERE TRIMMED OUT OF THE ONGOING FROST ADVISORY. MOS HAS DONE A POOR 
JOB OF HANDLING HOW LOW CURRENT DEW POINT TEMPS HAVE FALLEN...SO MIN 
RH THIS AFTERNOON SHOULD CERTAINLY BE QUITE LOW. HOWEVER...WIND 
SPEEDS WILL BE WELL BELOW RED FLAG WARNING LEVELS.

OTHERWISE...CYCLONIC FLOW ALOFT WILL GRADUALLY GIVE WAY TO RISING 
HEIGHTS...WHILE SURFACE RIDGE BUILDS SOUTHWARD INTO THE TN VALLEY 
AND SRN APPALACHIANS. EXPECT MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES AND A FEW AREAS WITH 
MINS IN THE 30S AGAIN TONIGHT. 

DUE TO LAST MINUTE UNCERTAINTY AND TO AVOID CONFUSION WITH THIS 
MORNING'S FROST ADVISORY...I OPTED NOT TO ISSUE A FROST ADVISORY FOR 
SUNDAY NIGHT.

.LONG TERM...(MONDAY THROUGH SATURDAY)...PATTERN IS CHANGING
SOMEWHAT THIS WEEK. INITIALLY MONDAY HIGH PRESSURE CENTERED OVER
THE WESTERN GREAT LAKES WILL KEEP SKIES MOSTLY SUNNY. MONDAY NIGHT
LOW PRESSURE AREA ALONG THE GULF COAST WILL TRACK EAST WITH
MOISTURE MOVING OVER THE FRONT. THIS BRINGS CLOUDS AND SLIGHT
CHANCE SHOWERS TO MOSTLY SOUTHERN SECTIONS MONDAY NIGHT AND
SPREADING NORTH TUESDAY AND THEN EAST OF THE FORECAST AREA TUESDAY
NIGHT. BEST CHANCE OF SHOWERS EASTERN MOUNTAINS AND SOUTHERN VALLEY
AND PLATEAU. WEAK HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS BACK IN WEDNESDAY. RIDGING
ALOFT EXPECTED TO KEEP FORECAST AREA DRY THROUGH FRIDAY WITH
WARMING TEMPERATURES. FRIDAY FRONTAL SYSTEM DEVELOPS OVER THE
PLAINS AND INCREASING MOISTURE SPREADS INTO THE TENNESSEE VALLEY.
THIS SHOULD BE A MORE SIGNIFICANT SYSTEM WITH A CHANCE OF
THUNDERSTORMS SATURDAY AND PRODUCE MORE SIGNIFICANT RAINFALL THAN
TUESDAYS. THE SYSTEM WILL BE A SLOWER MOVER AND BE STILL WEST OF
THE FORECAST AREA SATURDAY EVENING.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             72  43  71  48  67 /   0   0  10  20  30 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  68  41  68  45  66 /   0   0  10  20  30 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       67  41  69  45  66 /   0   0  10  10  30 
TRI CITIES AIRPORT, TN              64  36  66  39  67 /   0   0   0  10  20

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
427 AM EDT SAT APR 17 2010

.SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...WEAKENING SHOWERS ASSOCIATED WITH 
A COLD FRONT CONTINUE TO DROP SE INTO SW VA AND ALONG THE TN-KY 
STATE LINE THIS MORNING. OPTED TO RULE OUT ANY THUNDERSTORMS AT THIS 
POINT...WITH HIGHEST POPS GENERALLY IN THE GRIDS BEFORE 12Z TODAY. 
CURRENT TEMPS QUITE MILD IN ADVANCE OF THE FRONT. DON'T EXPECT ANY 
CHANCE OF SHOWERS AFTER THIS MORNING...AND MAX TEMPS SHOULD REACH 
NEAR THE WARMER MOS GUIDANCE. 

BRISK WINDS TODAY DON'T COMPLETELY DROP OFF TONIGHT...SO THIS SHOULD 
PREVENT AREAS OF FROST FROM FORMING. GFS MOS MINS LOOKED BETTER THAN 
COOLER NAM-WRF MINS DUE TO WINDS STAYING UP...GENERALLY ABOVE 
FREEZING VALUES. COLDER NIGHT WITH LIGHTER WINDS WILL BE SUNDAY 
NIGHT...WITH AREAS OF FROST LIKELY THEN.

.LONG TERM...(SUNDAY THROUGH FRIDAY)...SHORT RANGE MODELS SHOW HIGH
PRESSURE MOVING DOWN FROM THE NW WITH UPPER TROUGH ACROSS THE NE
STATES AND RIDGING OVER THE WESTERN STATES. COOL DRY AIR SUNDAY
WILL DROP HIGH TEMPERATURES SEVERAL MORE DEGREES. MOSTLY HIGHS IN
THE 60S BUT NEAR 70 AT CHA. SUNDAY NIGHT LOWS ABOUT THE SAME AS
SATURDAY BUT WITH LIGHT WINDS FROST POSSIBLE SW VA AND NE TN
VALLEYS AND SW NC LOWER ELEVATIONS MOST AT RISK. MONDAY SLIGHTLY
WARMER AS WELL AS MONDAY NIGHT AS UPPER TROUGH SHIFTS EAST. TUESDAY
WEAK LOW DEVELOPS OVER SE SOUTH OF FORECAST AREA BUT SLIGHT
INCREASE IN CLOUDS AND NO RAIN EXPECTED. HIGH PRESSURE STILL IN
CONTROL HOWEVER THROUGH WEDNESDAY NIGHT. GFS BRINGS SYSTEM DOWN IN
NW FLOW ALOFT BUT ECMWF HAS WEAK SYSTEM PASS THROUGH TUESDAY AND
THEN KEEPS DRY NW FLOW ALOFT IN CONTROL THROUGH FRIDAY. CHOSE TO
FOLLOW DRY FORECAST DEPICTED IN ECMWF WITH NO RAIN AND SLOWLY
WARMING TEMPERATURES AT NIGHT AND DURING THE DAY THROUGH THE END OF
THE FORECAST

TO MOVE THROUGH IN ADVANCE OF THE FRONT...BUT WITH LIMITED 
MOISTURE... RAINFALL AMOUNTS ARE EXPECTED TO BE RELATIVELY LIGHT.  
ALL ON TRACK WITH THE CURRENT FORECAST...WILL UPDATE TO REMOVE 
EVENING WORDING.

&&

953 
FXUS64 KMRX 161503
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1100 AM EDT FRI APR 16 2010

.DISCUSSION...FORECAST ON TRACK. SW WINDS PICKING UP IN ADVANCE OF 
APPROACHING COLD FRONT. POP CHC TOO LOW TO MENTION FOR TODAY. SON

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION:
SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...CLOUDS FROM REMNANTS OF 
THURSDAY'S CONVECTION HAVE DISSIPATED LEAVING MOSTLY CLEAR SKIES. 
MODELS QUITE CONSISTENT WITH PREVIOUS RUNS IN SHOWING THE UPPER 
RIDGE TO BREAK DOWN THIS AFTERNOON...AND ALLOW THE WEAK COLD FRONT 
TO SAG SE INTO AND THROUGH THE FORECAST AREA LATE TONIGHT.

INSTABILITY IS NOT VERY IMPRESSIVE NOR IS THERE MUCH IN THE WAY OF 
UPPER LEVEL SUPPORT FOR CONVECTION. PREVIOUS FORECAST GRIDS LOOKED 
ON TRACK...ALTHO I DID SLIGHTLY INCREASE POPS ACROSS OUR NRN PLATEAU 
AND SW VA COUNTIES WITH AN AREAL QUALIFIER (SCATTERED SHOWERS WITH 
ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS).

MOS GUIDANCE WAS TOO LOW ON MAX TEMPS FOR THURSDAY...SO TRENDED 
TOWARD OR JUST ABOVE THE WARMER MAXES...ESPECIALLY ACROSS CENTRAL 
AND SRN AREAS. MINIMUM RH INCREASES THIS AFTERNOON ABOVE ANY 
CRITICAL VALUES FOR FIRE WEATHER CONCERNS...ALTHO WINDS WILL BE 
BREEZY OVER SW VA AND NE TN. WILL LET DAY SHIFT CHECK WITH FIRE 
WEATHER DISTRICTS ON THE NEED FOR A FIRE DANGER STATEMENT.

LONG TERM...(SATURDAY THROUGH THURSDAY)...FORECAST MODELS HAVE WEAK 
COLD FRONT PASSING THROUGH THE FORECAST AREA SATURDAY MORNING. WILL 
KEEP SLIGHT CHANCE SHOWERS UNTIL ABOUT 18Z. HIGH PRESSURE BUILDS IN 
FROM THE NW LATE SATURDAY INTO SUNDAY. NW FLOW AND UPPER TROUGH 
ACROSS THE EASTERN STATES WILL ALLOW COOLER TEMPERATURES TO AFFECT 
THE REGION. HIGHS SATURDAY WILL BE MUCH COOLER SW VA AND NE TN SOME 
15 TO 20 DEGREES AND AROUND 10 DEGREES AT CHA. WINDS WILL BE FAIRLY 
STRONG WITH COLD AIR ADVECTION. SATURDAY NIGHT LOWS WILL DIP INTO 
THE MID 30S TO THE LOWER 40S. SUNDAYS HIGHS WILL LIKELY STAY IN THE 
50S HIGHER ELEVATIONS AND 60S ELSEWHERE. SUNDAY NIGHT ANOTHER COLD 
NIGHT WITH WINDS BECOMING LIGHT. FROST POSSIBLE WITH LOWS AGAIN IN 
THE 30S. HIGH PRESSURE WITH NORTHWEST FLOW CONTINUES TUESDAY THROUGH 
THURSDAY WITH A GRADUAL WARMING TREND AND LITTLE CHANCE FOR RAIN.
&&

FRAME. ECMWF MODEL IS SLIGHTLY SLOWER WITH THIS EVENT THAN EITHER 
THE NAM OR GFS. SREF ENSEMBLES TEND TO FAVOR NAM/GFS TIMING. THUS 
CONTINUED CHANCE POPS FOR MOST OF THE FORECAST AREA FRIDAY NIGHT AND 
SATURDAY AS PREVIOUSLY CONFIGURED. DRY REGIME RETURNS AS SURFACE 
HIGH PRESSURE AND NORTHWEST FLOW ALOFT BECOME ESTABLISHED. NORTHWEST 
FLOW ALOFT WILL KEEP TEMPS NEAR CLIMO INSTEAD OF THE 
MUCH-ABOVE-CLIMO TEMPS THAT HAVE PREVAILED RECENTLY. DID GO SLIGHTLY 
ABOVE MEX GUIDANCE FOR MAX TEMPS NEXT WEEK BASED ON GEFS ENSEMBLE 
TRENDS.

ANOTHER SYSTEM APPROACHES THE REGION BY LATE IN THE LONG TERM. 
SIGNIFICANT MODEL/ENSEMBLE DIFFERENCES WITH RESPECT TO TIMING AND 
INTENSITY RESULT IN LOW CONFIDENCE WITH THIS SYSTEM. DID INTRODUCE 
SLIGHT CHANCE POPS LATE IN THE LONG TERM HOWEVER.


&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
CHATTANOOGA AIRPORT, TN             55  83  54  83  55 /   0   0   0   0  20 
KNOXVILLE MCGHEE TYSON AIRPORT, TN  53  81  56  81  56 /   0   0   0  10  20 
OAK RIDGE, TN                       52  82  55  82  56 /   0   0   0  10  30 
TRI CITIES AIRPORT, TN              44  79  49  79  51 /   0   0   0  10  40 

&&

.MRX WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
NC...NONE.
TN...NONE.
VA...NONE.

SON/LCM

FXUS64 KMRX 141500
AFDMRX

AREA FORECAST DISCUSSION
NATIONAL WEATHER SERVICE MORRISTOWN TN
1100 AM EDT WED APR 14 2010

.DISCUSSION...FORECAST ON TRACK. WEAK FRONTAL BOUNDARY DRAPED ACROSS 
EXTREME NE PART OF MRX CWA. LOW LEVEL MOISTURE CAPPED BELOW 3600 
FEET EAST OF APPALACHIAN TRAIL. SON

PREVIOUS DISCUSSION:
SHORT TERM...(TODAY AND TONIGHT)...PERSISTENCE CONTINUES TO BE THE 
WAY TO GO WITH HIGH PRESSURE ANCHORED OVER THE EASTERN U.S.  THIS 
WILL KEEP DRY AND WARM CONDITIONS IN PLACE THROUGH THE SHORT TERM.  
ONLY CONCERN CONTINUES TO BE LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITIES AND WILL HAVE 
LOW RH HEADLINE IN FWF.

LONG TERM...(THURSDAY THROUGH TUESDAY)...MODELS IN DECENT AGREEMENT 
FOR BULK OF THE PERIOD.  SOME TIMING DIFFERENCES IN BRINGING FRONT 
THROUGH THE AREA FRIDAY NIGHT/SATURDAY...BUT GFS LOOKS LIKE A GOOD 
COMPROMISE SO WILL GENERALLY FOLLOW ITS TIMING.  UPPER RIDGE SHOULD 
HOLD THROUGH THURSDAY KEEPING THINGS DRY.  WILL CARRY SLIGHT CHANCE 
POPS NORTH AND CENTRAL FRIDAY AFTERNOON...SLIGHT CHANCE SOUTH AND 
CHANCE NORTH AND CENTRAL FRIDAY NIGHT...THEN CHANCE ALL ZONES 
SATURDAY GIVEN UNCERTAINTY IN FRONTAL TIMING. DRIER AIR FORECAST TO 
MOVE IN BEHIND THE FRONT AS HIGH PRESSURE TAKES CONTROL ONCE 
AGAIN...SO WILL KEEP FORECAST PRECIP FREE SUNDAY THROUGH TUESDAY.  
WILL GENERALLY STAY CLOSE TO GFS MOS TEMPS...WHICH LOOK REASONABLE 
OVERALL.
